data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>sell</kanji>ing that you've raised (<ja>上げ</ja>) is the <vocabulary>amount sold</vocabulary> or number of <vocabulary>sales</vocabulary>. Think of a graph going upward, where it's rising as you sell more things.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for <ja>売</ja> is the one you learned with <ja>売る</ja>. The reading for <ja>上げ</ja> is the same as the reading for <ja>上げる</ja>, a word you learned previously. If you know those two separate things, you should be able to combine them into one awesome vocab thing.

context_sentences.en: Sales gradually decreased.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>sell</kanji>ing is <kanji>cut</kanji>, that means something is <vocabulary>sold out</vocabulary>. You'll see this word a lot in stores (or, hopefully you won't...) in Japan. Look out for it if you're able!
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>hand</kanji> that <kanji>sell</kanji>s the items is connected to a person who is known as the <vocabulary>seller</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>vendor</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too! One hint that this is a kun'yomi reading word is the hiragana in the center. It's like two separate words combined together, and when a word is a single kanji / a single kanji with hiragana attached it is usually kun'yomi. This is like two of those, combined.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>start</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to start something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You start something. Like studying! You should have started studying earlier though, huh?
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

Right now it's time <vocabulary>to begin</vocabulary> <reading>Haj</reading> (<ja>はじ</ja>). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). You need to start Haj right now!

context_sentences.en: I don’t know what to start from.
context_sentences.ja: 何から始めるのがいいのか、分かりません。

context_sentences.en: Will your daughter start any extracurriculars when she reaches fourth grade?
context_sentences.ja: むすめさん、四年生になったら、何かならい事を始めるの？

context_sentences.en: You need to mix all the ingredients together before you can start transferring the batter to the pans.
context_sentences.ja: 生地をフライパンに流し始める前に、材料を全て混ぜる必要があります。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something starts. No direct object here. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to start</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as <ja>始める</ja>.

context_sentences.en: What time does the movie start?
context_sentences.ja: そのえいがは何時から始まりますか。

context_sentences.en: A fierce economic war between America and China has begun.
context_sentences.ja: アメリカと中国のしれつなけいざいせんそうが始まりました。

context_sentences.en: The sound of the rifle means the pie eating contest has started.
context_sentences.ja: 銃声が、大食いパイコンテストの始まりの合図となります。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know the kanji part means <kanji>begin</kanji>. The <ja>に</ja> on the end refers to a direction. So, think of this like "the direction of the beginning" which would be where things all started. That's why this word/phrase means "<vocabulary>in the beginning</vocabulary>."
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi (look at all that hiragana!) but that's the reading you learned with the word <ja>始める</ja>, so have no fear, you got it!

context_sentences.en: For this problem, please begin by listening to the question.
context_sentences.ja: このもんだいでは、始めにしつもんをきいてください。

context_sentences.en: Koichi's surprise birthday party went really well except that Kanae spilled soy sauce on his birthday cake in the beginning.
context_sentences.ja: 始めにカナエがたん生日ケーキにしょうゆをこぼしてしまったこと以外は、コウイチのサプライズバースデーパーティーは大せいこうでした。

context_sentences.en: What are the first words at the beginning of the Bible?
context_sentences.ja: 聖書の一番始めには何が書かれているの？

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>real</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is <vocabulary>the real thing</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>real deal</vocabulary>. 

If you learned <ja>本</ja> as <kanji>book</kanji> you can also think of this word as the "book thing." What is this book thing? Is it the real version of the book? Is it the real deal? If so, I'll pay you a million.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are on'yomi plus kun'yomi (kun'yomi is <ja>物</ja>). This word uses the reading you learned for both of these kanji, though, which means you should be able to read it.

context_sentences.en: Current CG is so realistic that it feels real at a first glance, and I think that’s really cool.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>乗り</ja> has something to do with <kanji>riding</kanji> and that <ja>物</ja> is a <kanji>thing</kanji>. So what is a "riding thing?" Nowadays, at least, that would be a <vocabulary>vehicle</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wait</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to wait</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: You need <vocabulary>to wait</vocabulary> for your <reading>ma</reading>ma (<ja>ま</ja>) all the time. You want to go out? You have to wait for mama to drive you. Want to eat dinner? You have to wait for mama to make you food. Hmm. Maybe all this waiting is really a you problem.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wait</kanji> so this word has something to do with waiting. Use the <ja>たせ</ja> as a hint. Someone "tossed" a ball off into a ditch, and then they had to find it. They made you wait for them to get the ball too, even though it's a cheap piece of crap. Feel upset about this.
data.reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading from <ja>待つ</ja>, congrats!

context_sentences.ja: お待たせしてすみません。いや〜バスにえらく長いこと待たされましてね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>hold</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> you are a <vocabulary>rich person</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Do you remember the word <ja>お金</ja>? This is the <ja>金</ja> in this word. The reading for <ja>持ち</ja> is the <ja>も</ja> you learned with <ja>持つ</ja>. So, combine the <ja>かね</ja> of <ja>お金</ja> and the <ja>持ち</ja> and you have the reading of this word. Alternatively, you can say this word as <ja>お金持ち</ja> as well.

context_sentences.en: He’s rich though…

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>energy</kanji> you <kanji>hold</kanji> in your body is your <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary>s. It can take the form of all kinds of things. Good feelings, bad feelings, that "strange feeling."

Now, don't confuse this with the future vocab word <ja>気持ちいい</ja> which means "good feeling." This one just means "feeling" because it doesn't have an adjective attached to it, telling you more about this feeling that you're having.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji, though <ja>気</ja> is on'yomi and <ja>持ち</ja> is kun'yomi. One of those weird exception readings, but it'll work out for you anyway, as long as you're studying the kanji well enough.

context_sentences.en: I know exactly how you feel.

context_sentences.ja: これ、つまらないものですが。ささやかな感謝の気持ちです。どうぞ、開けてみてください。

The <ja>する</ja> is on there to make this noun a verb. Without the <ja>する</ja> it would be the noun "broadcast."

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so tomorrow when you wake up you hopefully won't have to relearn this vocab's reading.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Doing something both <kanji>fast</kanji> and <kanji>early</kanji> probably requires you to do it <vocabulary>at once</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>immediately</vocabulary>. Whatever it is, be sure to do it <vocabulary>without delay</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is strange. The reading for <ja>速</ja> (<ja>そく</ja>) is what you'd expect (on'yomi), but <ja>早</ja> gets a reading you haven't seen before, meaning you should treat this as an exception. Just think about how you're learning this word <vocabulary>at once</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>without delay</vocabulary> so there's no time for any <reading>sa</reading>ss (<ja>さっ</ja>), just kanji learning.

data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>distribute</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to distribute</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have <vocabulary>to distribute</vocabulary> some fliers to everyone. On the fliers it talks about a striptease show where <reading>kubla</reading>i (<ja>くば</ja>) Khan does something naughty. Imagine this show, and imagine your shame of being the person handing out these fliers. How far the Khan has fallen.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is just the noun version of the kanji <ja>酒</ja> - it has an <ja>お</ja> there to be nice. This word can mean both <vocabulary>alcohol</vocabulary> (same like the parent kanji) or <vocabulary>sake</vocabulary> (the main kind of Japanese alcohol, at least back in the kanji days).
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi, which isn't what you learned with the kanji. But, it should be pretty easy. You know what Japanese alcohol is called already, right? It's <ja><reading>さけ</reading></ja>, simple as that. So long as you've heard of sake you should be A-Okay with this reading.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>日本</ja> is "Japan" so when you add <kanji>alcohol</kanji> onto the end of that you have <vocabulary>Japanese Style Alcohol</vocabulary> (what's the big Japanese style alcohol that everyone knows? That's <vocabulary>sake</vocabulary>).
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the vocab <ja>日本</ja>'s reading plus the reading you learned for <ja>酒</ja>, put together.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji here means <kanji>revolve</kanji>. The verb version of this is similar. It means <vocabulary>to roll</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tumble</vocabulary>. When something is doing these things it is revolving, right?

Imagine something rolling down a hill. Inside is a very important uranium <reading>core</reading> (<ja>ころ</ja>) that you need to keep spinning. That's why they have it rolling down hill after hill, because they don't have anything else to keep it spinning like that, preventing it from exploding. This core is very important!

Just imagine yourself on a bike, and you don't even have to move the pedals. They revolve themselves, but now you're going too fast and it's scary.

data.meaning_mnemonic: So there's this weird thing with Japanese people. Many things that most people would consider "green" are actually "blue" in their eyes. So, things like plants and street lights are "blue" even though you may think of them as green. Remember that for this word, where we talk about a <kanji>blue</kanji> <kanji>leaf</kanji>. In your head, though, think "green leaf." Now think of all things that have green leaves. This is <vocabulary>greenery</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi readings. Since you've already seen the word <ja>青</ja>, hopefully you can just combine it with <ja>葉</ja> (you learned the reading for this part with the kanji). Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku, though. <ja>は</ja> goes to <ja>ば</ja> in this word, making it <ja><reading>あおば</reading></ja>.

data.reading_mnemonic:

When you only have one thing, there's only one thing. Nothing is collected. But when you have two... "<reading>ah two</reading>!" (<ja>あつ</ja>). Now you're starting <vocabulary>to collect</vocabulary> things.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>language</kanji> about <kanji>thing</kanji>s. This is a confusing one. Just think of it more like someone talking about things, anything, really. Someone who just talks about things is someone who tells stories. So, this word means <vocabulary>tale</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>story</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>legend</vocabulary> (not the Tom Cruise one, though).
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is messed up. You have <ja>物</ja> as <ja>もの</ja>, which is fine, but <ja>語</ja> decides to go all crazy on you. Maybe you've heard the word <ja>ものがたり</ja> before (it's in some film names / book names). If not, think of a story being told about a great <reading>gatling</reading> (<ja>がたり</ja>) gun that wandered the land, mowing everything down in its path. It's a terrible legend, but what if it were true???

context_sentences.en: I think she's acting like she's the main character of a story.

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go read something else, now.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that this has something to do with <kanji>read</kanji>ing and you know that <ja>方</ja> means <kanji>way</kanji> or <kanji>method</kanji>. So, when you think of a "way of reading" you can think of a couple other better words, such as <vocabulary>reading</vocabulary> (aka the reading of a word) or <vocabulary>pronunciation</vocabulary>. Anytime you need to know how something sounds, this is what you'll ask for.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, but they're the readings you've learned with the kanji. <ja>方</ja> is like many other words you've come across as well, such as <ja>見方</ja> or <ja>作り方</ja>.

data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You're starting <vocabulary>to compete</vocabulary> with your rival. You're yelling, and punching each other in the faces, causing a huge scene, and making people call the cops on you. Because of your quarrel, you have both now been <reading>arres</reading>ted (<ja>あらそ</ja>) and are now spending time in prison. This isn't the perfect reading, but it hopefully can get you to the correct reading with a few tries. Try to make the connection.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>release</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to release</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Imagine you are going <vocabulary>to release</vocabulary> something. It is a <ja><reading>花</reading></ja> (<ja>はな</ja>). You release it from your hand and it falls, hitting the ground in slow motion. You have the power to release and you are doing the releasing (versus <ja>放れる</ja> where something is just released). You can remember this because even though you did the releasing of the flower, you're going to sue the pavement company for breaking your flower. It's all a big scam you're running.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>wave</kanji> is a wave of electricity going through the air. There are many words one can use to describe this, but the easiest one is <vocabulary>reception</vocabulary> (aka the reception on your phone, for example). Other more technical meanings are <vocabulary>radio wave</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>electromagnetic waves</vocabulary>. Which one you like is up to you, but reception is going to be the most common meaning on the street. Luckily people in Japan don't have AT&T otherwise you'd hear this word a lot more...

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>way</kanji>/<kanji>road</kanji> of the <kanji>god</kanji>(s) is, as you can probably guess, a big Japanese religion. There's two, and I'll give you a hint, this one isn't Buddhism (that would probably have the kanji for Buddha in it, no?). So what's the other big one? It's <vocabulary>Shinto</vocabulary>. If you're having trouble remembering this because you've never heard of it before, skip to the reading. The reading will help.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit wonky. <ja>神</ja> should be no problem. <ja>道</ja> on the other hand is almost the one you learned (<ja>どう</ja>) but now it's <ja>とう</ja> for some reason. Perhaps the gods took away the dakuten to make it <ja>とう</ja>, who knows. All I know is that it's best not to question said gods. If you already know of Shinto in English, though, this reading should be really easy. If you don't, perhaps you can use this reading to help you to remember Shinto the religion.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>God</kanji> <kanji>company</kanji>... think of this as "what 'company' does the god's work?" Well, the answer to that is a shrine, probably. In this case a <vocabulary>Shinto Shrine</vocabulary> because of the <ja>しん</ja> in the <ja>神</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic: But wait! <ja>神</ja> is read <ja>じん</ja> in this word for some reason. Darn them gods, always messing around, adding dakuten. Maybe this will help, though: Imagine yourself at a Shinto Shrine. You are praying to the Gods, asking for food. Out from the sky rains <reading>Ginger</reading> (<ja>じんじゃ</ja>). You are pelted with it and not sure if you should be happy or upset.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stream</kanji>, but what in the world could "to stream" be (remember, there weren't streams of StarCraft II games back in the day when this word was made up)? Well, let's think water. If you're streaming water, it's going <vocabulary>to flow</vocabulary>. Alternatively, <vocabulary>to flush</vocabulary> works too.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You have <vocabulary>to flush</vocabulary> them down the toilet. Imagine someone nagging you to do your chores so you flush them down the toilet, somehow.

data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're holding onto a <vocabulary>sports ball</vocabulary> in your hand, let's say it's a baseball for this mnemonic's sake. You throw it at your friend who's going to catch it. As it flies through the air, though, it transforms into a <reading>toma</reading>hawk (<ja>たま</ja>). Imagine your shock and fear as you see this happening, flying towards your friend! It's going to stick in his forehead. He can't catch this with his glove! 

Also notice that it has the same reading as the vocab word <ja>玉</ja>. So, if you know that one, you may know this one too! They're kind of similar.

This can be read <ja>きゅう</ja> too, if you're talking about more of a globe sphere than the ball sphere you throw.

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is on'yomi because it's a jukugo word but <ja>がく</ja> gets shortened to <ja>がっ</ja>, so be careful. Maybe you just wish the school term would get shorter which is why you shortened <ja>がく</ja> like that?

This is talking about a <vocabulary>season</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>period</vocabulary> of time, not the concept of time itself. That would be <ja>時間</ja> or something.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>tooth</kanji> <kanji>bug</kanji>... Luckily, it's not some bug living in your tooth, though you can see why someone might think this is what happens. A tooth with a "bug" in it is a tooth with a <vocabulary>cavity</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned with these kanji. Notice that <ja>は</ja> turns to <ja>ば</ja>, though. Presumably this is because you might yell out "BAH!" when you find out you have a cavity.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <ja>い</ja> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>warm</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>warm</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Touch something that's warm... too warm! You pull your hand back and go "<reading>AH ta ta!</reading> (<ja>あたた</ja>). People make this noise when they touch something that's hot, I hear. It's almost like saying "hot hot hot" while dropping the "h" sound.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Hot water</kanji>'s <kanji>energy</kanji> isn't the hot water itself, it's what comes out of it (when it's boiling, for example). This is the <vocabulary>steam</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>vapor</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The <ja>ゆ</ja> part of the reading makes sense. The <ja>げ</ja> part for <ja>気</ja> is a bit of an exception. Just think of yourself standing in the steams and vapors. You're getting all hot and sweaty, but the feeling makes you incredibly happy and <reading>gay</reading> (<ja>げ</ja>). Then someone asks, as they look at you in the steam: "Hey, <reading>you gay</reading>?" (<ja>ゆげ</ja>). You answer however you want to answer.

context_sentences.en: This vapors coming out of Viet's forehead smell nice for some reason.

The kanji itself means <kanji>climb</kanji> so the verb vocab version would be <vocabulary>to climb</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to ascend</vocabulary>), if that's the kind of thing you're into.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This has the same reading as <ja>上る</ja> which you learned all that time ago in Level 1. If you can remember that, you can remember this one!

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Climb</kanji> a <kanji>mountain</kanji>. That is <vocabulary>mountain climbing</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note this uses the alternative <ja>と</ja> reading, not to be confused with <ja>とう</ja> (actually, very confusing, sorry!). Just imagine you cut your <reading>toe</reading> off with an ice pick while mountain climbing. You know it's a short <ja>と</ja> because your toe is now short. And <ja>さん</ja> becomes <ja>ざん</ja> thanks to our old friend rendaku.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wear</kanji> so this word means <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary>. You'll need to differentiate it from <ja>着く</ja> which means (to arrive), though. Just think of how the <ja>る</ja> is the <reading>ru</reading>de guy trying to get you to wear things you don't like wearing.
data.reading_mnemonic: What do you want <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary> today? How about a dress made entirely of <reading>key</reading>s (<ja>き</ja>)? Feel the metal on your skin and the weight on your shoulders. It's not a comfortable thing to put on. Maybe just stick with wearing a single key around your neck next time.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word is tough, because there's another word in this level (<ja>着る</ja>) that means "to wear" that is so similar. This word, however, means <vocabulary>to arrive</vocabulary>. You should have seen that meaning with the kanji <ja>着</ja> as well, so I hope that helps. To differentiate between this and <ja>着る</ja>, though, zoom in on the <ja>く</ja>. You want to be <reading>coo</reading>l (<ja>く</ja>) so you arrive to the party late.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This uses a different kun'yomi reading than the one you just learned (sorry). To help you, think about this:

You wanted <vocabulary>to arrive</vocabulary> on time but you showed up late. How late were you? <reading>Two</reading> (<ja>つ</ja>) hours and two minutes late, to be exact.

context_sentences.en: My father told me that companies that cut back on leadership training to save money in the short term are a penny wise and pound foolish.
context_sentences.ja: 私は父に、短期的なコスト削減のためにリーダーシップ研修を縮小している企業は、一文惜しみの百知らずだと教えられました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're looking at a natural <vocabulary>spring</vocabulary> in the ground. Water is bubbling up, but then something changes. It looks a bit clogged... something is poking out. Then, all of a sudden, Mario flies out of the springs, falls in front of you and yells: "<reading>izumeeeee</reading> (<ja>いずみ</ja>), Mario!"

context_sentences.en: We're drinking water from the spring.
context_sentences.ja: わたしたちは、泉からのわき水を飲んでいます。

context_sentences.en: There are a lot of geese in that spring.
context_sentences.ja: その泉にはがちょうがたくさんいます。

context_sentences.en: Wow! You look beautiful! Did you go on a special diet? Or did you find the Fountain of Youth?
context_sentences.ja: わぁ！すごく綺麗。何か特別なダイエットでもしたの？それとも、若返りの泉でも見つけたとか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know the word <ja>外来</ja> to mean "imported." So, combine that with the kanji for <kanji>language</kanji> and you have an imported word, aka a <vocabulary>borrowed word</vocabulary>. There are a lot of these in Japanese, which makes this word important. Almost everything in katakana is a <ja>外来語</ja>, in fact.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Many Japanese words are used as loanwords in modern day Chinese.
context_sentences.ja: げんざいの中国語では、たくさんの日本語が外来語として使われています。

context_sentences.en: Is rucksack a foreign word, or Engrish?
context_sentences.ja: リュックサックは、外来語ですか？それとも和せいえい語ですか？

context_sentences.en: Hey, did you know that there's kanji for the word tobacco even though it’s a loanword?
context_sentences.ja: ねえ、煙草って外来語なのに漢字があるって知ってた？

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>suit</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to suit</vocabulary>. 

This word also means <vocabulary>to come together</vocabulary> as well. Presumably when something suits something else, it comes together with it flawlessly. That's why this word also has this other meaning (and it will be important for future vocab as well).
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to find a pet <vocabulary>to suit</vocabulary> your personal style, so you get matched with an <reading>a</reading>ardvark (<ja>あ</ja>). An aardvark will match the ant mounds you use for chairs and couches, it's the perfect match.

context_sentences.en: Red wine pairs well with meat dishes.
context_sentences.ja: 肉りょうりには赤ワインが合います。

context_sentences.en: You should try it on to see if it suits you.
context_sentences.ja: 合うかどうか、しちゃくしてかくにんした方がいいよ。

context_sentences.en: Indian cuisine in America is altered quite a bit from how it’s prepared in India to suit American tastes.
context_sentences.ja: アメリカのインド料理は、アメリカ人の口に合うよう、実際のインドでの調理方法とはかなり違った方法で作られている。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <ja>当て</ja> means something like <kanji>to guess correctly</kanji>. <ja>字</ja> means <kanji>letter</kanji>. So, this is a letter you guessed correctly. This refers to <vocabulary>phonetic kanji</vocabulary>, which are kanji that are used in words simply for their sounds, not for their meanings. They are there to be phonetic, and that is all. That is why this word refers to <vocabulary>phonetic kanji</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi reading for <ja>字</ja> and the kun'yomi reading for <ja>当て</ja>. You've seen <ja>当てる</ja> in the past, though, so you should be able to read this portion as well. Combine the two together and you have yourself a nice reading.

context_sentences.en: "利休酒" are the phonetic kanji used for "liqueur."
context_sentences.ja: 「リキュール」には、「利休酒」という当て字が使われます。

context_sentences.en: Lately, there've been a lot of kids with bizarre names using phonetic kanji.
context_sentences.ja: 近ごろは、当て字を使ったキラキラネームを持つ子どもがたくさんいます。

context_sentences.en: Sometimes kanji are selected solely for their sounds and the meaning is ignored as in 亜米利加 (アメリカ). These are called phonetic kanji.
context_sentences.ja: 時々、漢字は、亜米利加 (アメリカ)のようにそれぞれの意味を無視して、読み方だけで選ばれます。これらの漢字を当て字と言います。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>sell</kanji> something <kanji>cheap</kanji>, you're selling it at a <vocabulary>discount</vocabulary>. Alternatively you can remember this word as <vocabulary>sell cheaply</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bargain sale</vocabulary>. These are good deals!
data.reading_mnemonic: The hiragana on the end hints that the readings are the kun'yomi readings. Use your memory of <ja>安い</ja> and <ja>売る</ja> to help you to remember how to read this.

context_sentences.en: If you sell yourself too short, it’ll be tough later.
context_sentences.ja: あんまり自分を安売りすると、後で辛くなりますよ。

context_sentences.en: I really love this jacket, but can't afford it. Are there any upcoming sales?
context_sentences.ja: このジャケット、めっちゃ好きだけど、ちょっとよゆうがないんですよね。近々安売りするよていとかってないですかね？

context_sentences.en: Yes, the TV was broken when I sold it to you, but that’s why it was on sale.
context_sentences.ja: そうだよ。君に売った時にはそのテレビは壊れていたさ。でも、だからこそ安売りしたんじゃないか。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Do you remember <ja>医者</ja> (doctor)? What happens when you add <kanji>eye</kanji> on there? You have yourself an <vocabulary>eye doctor</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the vocab word <ja>医者</ja> (<ja>いしゃ</ja>) plus the reading <ja>目</ja> (<ja>め</ja>), the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

context_sentences.en: My eye started hurting yesterday, I went to the eye doctor, and it was a sty.
context_sentences.ja: きのう目がいたくなって、目医者に行ったら、ものもらいだった。

context_sentences.en: I'm looking for an eye doctor who is open on weekends.
context_sentences.ja: 週末も開いている目医者をさがしています。

context_sentences.en: Listen, Mr. Eye Doctor. The cat's out of the bag, so there's no need to pretend you don’t know anything about eyes.
context_sentences.ja: 「よお、目医者さん。もう何もかもばれているんだよ。だから、目について何も知らないふりをする必要はないぜ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen <ja>一番</ja> (number one), so what in the world is this eye on the end? This eye (<ja>目</ja>) signifies the order. So, add this to "number one" and you have the <vocabulary>first thing</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>the first</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is just the vocab word <ja>一番</ja> plus the word <ja>目</ja>. If you know both of those readings you'll be able to read this one as well.

context_sentences.en: The first thing that comes to mind after finishing this wonderful breakfast is that bacon is delicious, as we all know.
context_sentences.ja: このごうかな朝食を食べ終わって、一番目のかんそうは、やっぱりベーコンはおいしい、です。

context_sentences.en: Please write down the name of the person you like in the first column.
context_sentences.ja: 一番目のらんには、すきな人の名前をかいてください。

context_sentences.en: "The first thing I do every morning is run five kilometers." "Big deal! I run ten!"
context_sentences.ja: 「僕は毎朝一番目に、5キロのランニングをするんだぜ。」「大したことないよ！僕は10キロ走るよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>return</kanji> the <kanji>doing</kanji>s of another person, you're doing it to <vocabulary>get even</vocabulary> (whether it's a nice thing or a mean thing).
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are a bit weird, here. <ja>仕</ja> gets its on'yomi reading... you should be okay with that. <ja>返し</ja> gets the kun'yomi reading, though, which is the reading you saw with the word <ja>返す</ja> in level 9. You can tell this part uses the kun'yomi vocab reading because it has that hiragana attached to it. Just remember to distinguish between the two parts of the word to remember the readings.

context_sentences.en: It was mortifying, so I wanna get even.
context_sentences.ja: くやしいから、なんか仕返ししたいな。

context_sentences.en: Catwoman! You are so evil! I’ll get you back soon!
context_sentences.ja: キャットウーマン！あんたって本当に最低の女だね！いつか仕返ししてやるわ！

context_sentences.en: I ate Koichi's favorite yogurt to get back at him for eating my pudding.
context_sentences.ja: プリンを食べられた仕返しに、コウイチの大すきなヨーグルトを食べてやった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the word <ja>楽しい</ja>, which means "fun." This is obviously very similar looking, though this one means <vocabulary>looking forward to</vocabulary>. Why? Because it has a <ja>み</ja> on the end, saying "who is going to have fun? It's <reading>me</reading>! That's why I'm looking forward to it!"
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is just like <ja>楽しい</ja>, so make sure you know that and you'll be able to read this one as well.

context_sentences.en: I’m looking forward to seeing you.
context_sentences.ja: あなたに会うのが楽しみです。

context_sentences.en: I think there are lots of different fun activities during summer break, like going to beach and camping and stuff.
context_sentences.ja: 夏休みの楽しみと言えば、海にキャンプに色々あると思いますよ。

context_sentences.en: We are all looking forward to burning turtles, aren’t we?
context_sentences.ja: 私達、みんな亀を燃やすのを楽しみにしているんだよね？

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <ja>向く</ja> and <ja>向ける</ja> by now. They mean "to face" and "to turn toward." This has a similar idea. When you add <ja>向け</ja> to something imagine you're turning it, aiming it at someone. It's aimed at them, meaning it's <vocabulary>made for</vocabulary> them. Turn a book toward someone, now it's <vocabulary>aimed at</vocabulary> them, it's made for them. See the connection?
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word <ja>向く</ja> so work off of that word to be able to read this one.

context_sentences.en: This work isn’t intended for children.
context_sentences.ja: これは子ども向けの作ひんではないですよね。

context_sentences.en: This curry was made for Japanese tastes.
context_sentences.ja: このカレーは、日本人向けのあじですね。

context_sentences.en: Aren’t the underpants Koichi is wearing for children? He’s outgrown his clothes.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチが履いてるパンツは、子供向けなんじゃないのか？ツンツルテンだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen that <ja>研究</ja> is research from previous vocab. So, a "place" that is a research place could be many things, though mainly a <vocabulary>research institute</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>research laboratory</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know the reading of <ja>研究</ja> already. Also note that <ja>所</ja> is normal for one reading, but also gets the rendaku treatment, meaning <ja>しょ</ja> becomes <ja>じょ</ja>, for the secondary reading.

context_sentences.en: I heard that a certain American lab has made a pill that will make you fluent in Japanese.
context_sentences.ja: とあるアメリカの研究所が、日本語がペラペラになるくすりを開発したそうだ。

context_sentences.en: There is an emergency drill in the Miso Soup Research Facility today.
context_sentences.ja: 今日は、みそしる研究所で、ぼうさいくんれんがあります。

context_sentences.en: I work for the Burger King Research Institute. My job consists of eating french fries and then having my body weighed.
context_sentences.ja: 私はバーガーキング研究所で働いています。私の仕事は、フライドポテトを食べ、その後自分の体重を測ることです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Taking the <kanji>nearby</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> will get you to your destination more quickly (because it's more close by!). This is a <vocabulary>shortcut</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>short way</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird in this one. Its kun'yomi reading for both kanji, even though it looks just like it should be all on'yomi reading. It's like you're taking a <vocabulary>shortcut</vocabulary> with your kanji readings and doing the native Japanese readings (kun'yomi) instead of the more intellectual Chinese ones (on'yomi). Luckily, you've hopefully seen both of these kanji as vocab already. You have <ja>ちか</ja> for <ja>近</ja> (short for <ja>近い</ja>) and you have <ja>道</ja> (<ja>みち</ja>), just like the word "street" you learned before. Combine these together and you have the reading for this word. Perhaps it's like this because you're combining a couple concepts together into one word, at least when it comes to "short + way."

context_sentences.en: Tracing a good picture is a shortcut for improvement.
context_sentences.ja: 上手な絵をも写する事は、上たつの近道です。

context_sentences.en: Do you really think memorizing kanji on WaniKani is actually a shortcut to Japanese acquisition?
context_sentences.ja: ワニカニで漢字をおぼえることは、本当に日本語習とくの近道になると思いますか？

context_sentences.en: "Oh my God! You are such an airhead! Why are we going down a one-way street?" "I thought it would be a shortcut!"
context_sentences.ja: 「ありえねぇ！お前って本当脳みそ無いのな。なんで一方通行を逆走してるんだよ。」「近道になると思ったんだよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic:
You know that <ja>助ける</ja> means "to help" - so, this is a different version of that. This is when someone is helping someone else, or something is helping you, but you're not doing the action of helping someone. Use the <ja>か</ja> to help you remember: The "car" helps you to drive around. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to be helped</vocabulary>. 

It also can be used to talk about how you were rescued, which is like being helped, right? If you want to memorize it that way, that's fine too.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>助ける</ja>, so hopefully you know that word and can apply that knowledge over here.

context_sentences.en: Is there still a chance it will be saved?
context_sentences.ja: まだ助かる見こみはあるんですか。

context_sentences.en: I was rescued by the relationship advice that my teacher Koichi gave me.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチ先生にもらったれんあいのアドバイスのおかげで、助かりました。

context_sentences.en: "So, are we going out or what? Make it clear!" "Um…" (The front doorbell rings: ring-ring.) "Phew, saved by the bell."
context_sentences.ja: 「で、私達付き合ってるのよね？どうなの？はっきりさせてよ。」「えーと…」＜その時、インターホンが鳴った。:ピンポーン＞「ふぅ、間一髪で助かった。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: There is an <kanji>interval</kanji> (of time) that you need "to meet" (<ja>合う</ja>). You need to be there before then. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to be in time for</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading for <ja>間</ja> when you learned <ja>間もなく</ja>. And the reading for <ja>合う</ja> is just that of the word <ja>合う</ja>. If you remember them both, you'll remember this word!

context_sentences.en: If we get in a taxi right now, we might still make it on time.
context_sentences.ja: 今すぐタクシーに乗れば、まだ間に合うかもしれません。

context_sentences.en: Sorry! I'm stuck in traffic, so I'm most likely not going to make it to the appointment on time.
context_sentences.ja: ごめん！じゅうたいにはまっちゃって、待ち合わせに間に合いそうにない。

context_sentences.en: "Do you think we can make it in time?" "Well, it’s almost seven o’clock. Do the math."
context_sentences.ja: 「間に合うと思う？」「もうすぐ7時なんだから、後は自分で考えればわかるだろ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You hopefully know the word <ja>返す</ja>, which means "to return" (as in, you're doing the direct action of returning something). This word, on the other hand, is the version where something just returns (and you're not doing the action of returning). Use the <ja>る</ja> to help you to remember this. <ja>る</ja> the Kangaroo is returned to you. You don't do any of the returning, it just happens or someone else does it. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to be returned</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>返す</ja>, so as long as you know that you'll be able to apply it here to learn the reading of this word as well.

context_sentences.en: When he came to, he was lying on the sofa in the Tofugu office.
context_sentences.ja: われに返ると、かれはトーフグオフィスのソファーに横たわっていた。

context_sentences.en: The precious keepsake pendant from my mom that I thought I'd lost was returned to me before I knew it.
context_sentences.ja: 失くしたと思っていた大事な母の形見のペンダントが気づいたら手元に返ってきていた。

context_sentences.en: Thinking my money would be returned properly was a huge mistake.
context_sentences.ja: 貸したお金がちゃんと返ってくると思ったら大間違いよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen the word <ja>楽しい</ja>, which means "fun." Now you're going to figure out the verb version (ends in an <ja>う</ja> sound, right?) of it. That would be <vocabulary>to enjoy</vocabulary>. Speaking of which, I hope you're enjoying WaniKani so far!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word <ja>楽しい</ja>, so be sure to know that word and you'll be able to apply it over here.

context_sentences.en: You can enjoy the beautiful ocean view from the window.
context_sentences.ja: まどから、海の美しいけ色を楽しむことができます。

context_sentences.en: We are having a lot of fun with this project.
context_sentences.ja: このプロジェクト、みんなすごく楽しみながらやってます。

context_sentences.en: Snap out of it, Usagi. Forget Tuxedo Mask and enjoy your life!
context_sentences.ja: うさぎちゃん、いい加減目を覚ましなって。タキシード仮面のことなんか忘れて、うさぎちゃんはうさぎちゃんの人生を楽しんだらいいんだよ！

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the word <ja>決める</ja> before, hopefully. This is similar, except for instead of doing the action of deciding, something has just been decided (by something or someone else). You are not the decision maker, here. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to be decided</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>決める</ja>, so make sure you know that word so you can apply that knowledge over here.

context_sentences.en: Since I got the job, I’ve lost interest.
context_sentences.ja: 仕事が決まってからは、きょうみがなくなりました。

context_sentences.en: Every morning Koichi is late for work because he hasn't decided on a hairstyle yet.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは毎朝かみがたが決まらないせいで会社にちこくする。

context_sentences.en: "That’s a really good idea. Let’s do that." "Okay, then it’s been decided."
context_sentences.ja: 「それは本当にいい考えだね。そうしよう。」「よし、じゃあ、それで話は決まりだ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that you're <kanji>throw</kanji>ing something that is <kanji>attach</kanji>ing to something else. How else can you say that? The best way would be to say <vocabulary>to throw against</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to throw at</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings just come from two vocab words you've hopefully seen already: <ja>投げる</ja> and <ja>付ける</ja>. So long as you know the readings for those words, the reading for this word should be no problem for you.

context_sentences.en: My daughter threw a vase at my head and gave me a serious injury that needed seven stitches.
context_sentences.ja: むすめから、頭に花びんを投げ付けられて、七はりをぬう大けがを負いました。

context_sentences.en: On the Setsubun, we threw dried beans at Koichi and chased the evil spirits away.
context_sentences.ja: せつ分の日にコウイチにまめを投げ付けてじゃ気をはらいました。

context_sentences.en: "Salmon, I’m mad about you." "Fugu, I’m actually mad at you! Why did you throw garlic at me? "S..sorry I’ve heard that salmon like the smell of garlic."
context_sentences.ja: 「サーモン、僕は君に夢中なんだ。」「フグ、私はあんたに怒り心頭よ。どうして私に向かってニンニクなんて投げ付けるのよ！」「ご…ごめん。鮭はニンニクの臭いが好きって聞いたことがあったんだ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the word <ja>化ける</ja> (to transform) before. Now we have a similar word. This word means <vocabulary>to bewitch</vocabulary> because when you cuss (<ja>かす</ja>) you are saying a magic word and bewitching the person in front of you. Imagine yourself yelling out cuss words, and every time a new enchantment falls upon your victim.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>化ける</ja>, so make sure you know that word and you'll be able to learn this word's reading as well.

context_sentences.en: Tanuki and foxes are good at bewitching humans.
context_sentences.ja: たぬきやきつねは、人間を化かすのがとくいだ。

context_sentences.en: My friend enchants men with makeup all the time.
context_sentences.ja: わたしの友人はいつも化しょうで男の人を化かしています。

context_sentences.en: "I’m sorry I’m late. I was bewitched by a fox." "No worries. Things like that can’t be helped."
context_sentences.ja: 「遅くなってすみません。いやあ、きつねに化かされちまってねえ。」「心配しないでください。それはどうしようもないことですからね。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji version of <ja>話</ja> means <kanji>talk</kanji>. This word also means <vocabulary>talk</vocabulary>, but it means a few other things as well. This can refer to a <vocabulary>speech</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>story</vocabulary> as well. Basically anything that involves a talking session. So, before you go, I hope you stay awhile and listen to my <ja>話</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Who tells a great <vocabulary>story</vocabulary>? <reading>Hana, she</reading> (<ja>はなし</ja>) tells a great story! If you know someone named Hana or Hanna you can use that person to help you to remember this one better too. 

You can also use <ja>話す</ja>'s reading to help you to remember this one, as well.

context_sentences.en: And then you will listen to the story and choose the best answer between 1-4 on the answer sheet.
context_sentences.ja: それから話を聞いて、もんだい用紙の１から４の中から、一番いいものを一つえらんでください。

context_sentences.en: I didn't sign up for this!
context_sentences.ja: 話がちがうよ！

context_sentences.en: "Now, I’d also like to say something else, Brittany!" "Jeremy! Give it a rest! I’m tired of listening to you."
context_sentences.ja: 「それから、私、他にも言いたいことがあるのよ、ブリタニー！」「ジェレミー、いい加減黙ってくれないか！君の話はもう聞き飽きたよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've probably seen the words <ja>知る</ja> and <ja>合う</ja> by now. This is someone you "know" because you had the chance to "meet" them, but that's pretty much it. You don't really know them, you just met them a couple times so you know who they are. This person is an <vocabulary>acquaintance</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are that of <ja>知る</ja> and <ja>合う</ja>. So long as you know those words, you should be able to read this one too.

context_sentences.en: I asked an acquaintance if they could get me Koichi’s autograph from Tofugu.
context_sentences.ja: 知り合いにたのんで、トーフグのコウイチからサインをもらいました。

context_sentences.en: I’m consulting my acquaintance about my relationship with my boyfriend right now, so I probably won’t be able to join the karaoke party. Sorry!
context_sentences.ja: 今知り合いにれんあい相だんしてるから、カラオケには行けないかも。ごめんね！

context_sentences.en: Don’t tell a soul but my boss is having an affair with a married woman who is an acquaintance of mine.
context_sentences.ja: ここだけの話なんだけど、上司が知り合いの人妻と浮気しているのよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the word <ja>乗る</ja> by now, hopefully, and know it means "to ride." So this word has to do with a "riding location." Where do you go to get a ride somewhere? Most likely, it's a <vocabulary>bus stop</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>taxi stand</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings, which you've learned already. Also, use <ja>乗る</ja> to help you to remember the reading for <ja>乗り</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Where is the gondola terminal?
context_sentences.ja: ゴンドラ乗り場はどこですか？

context_sentences.en: I'm waiting for a taxi in the airport taxi stand right now.
context_sentences.ja: 空港のタクシー乗り場でタクシーを待っているところです。

context_sentences.en: At the moment, I’m chilling at the bus stop in front of my house looking at cars passing by.
context_sentences.ja: 今、家の前のバス乗り場で通り過ぎる車を見ながらダラダラしているよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the word <ja>使う</ja> hopefully by now. If you have, you know it means "to use." So, the <kanji>way</kanji> to <kanji>use</kanji> something is the <vocabulary>way of using</vocabulary> (aka <vocabulary>how to use</vocabulary>). This will be a word you see when you're looking at directions for how to use something.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the vocab words <ja>使う</ja> and <ja>方</ja>. So long as you're okay with those you can apply that knowledge over here.

context_sentences.en: You should be more careful about how you use language.
context_sentences.ja: もう少し、言葉の使い方に気を付けた方がいいでしょ。

context_sentences.en: I don't know how to use iPhones.
context_sentences.ja: アイフォンの使い方が分かりません。

context_sentences.en: I’m going to train my dog how to use a hammer and bring him to work with me.
context_sentences.ja: 一緒に仕事ができるように、俺の犬に金槌の使い方を訓練してみようと思うんだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your "<kanji>doing</kanji> <kanji>action</kanji>s" are the things you do. What do you say when someone asks "what you do"? You tell them what your <vocabulary>job</vocabulary> is.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for <ja>仕</ja> and the kun'yomi reading for <ja>事</ja>. Please note that <ja>事</ja> uses the reading <ja>こと</ja>, which you didn't learn with the kanji, but you have come across it once or twice by now, and because of the way rendaku works, it's changed to the voiced <ja>ごと</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Does this job reimburse transportation costs?
context_sentences.ja: この仕事は、交通ひこみですか？

context_sentences.en: The business of a baby is to cry.
context_sentences.ja: 赤ちゃんの仕事は泣くことです。

context_sentences.en: "Do you think we can finish this work in time?" "Well I wouldn’t bet on it."
context_sentences.ja: 「時間内に、この仕事を終えられると思うか？」「さあ、それはどうかな。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully come across <ja>負ける</ja> by now, which means "to lose." So, you can figure out this word means "losing dog." Well, calling someone a dog isn't so nice, so you're probably just calling them a <vocabulary>loser</vocabulary>. As Ace Ventura would say: "Lehuzeherrrr. LOSER."
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi, but you should be familiar with <ja>負ける</ja> and of course <ja>犬</ja> well enough to learn the reading here.

context_sentences.en: I'm aware that I'm a loser who loves to just stay home and watch TV all day.
context_sentences.ja: 自分が、一日中家にいて、テレビばっかりみてる負け犬だってことは自かくしているよ。

context_sentences.en: I can't stand the fact that the loser is taking over my job tomorrow.
context_sentences.ja: あの負け犬が明日からおれの仕事を引きつぐとか、本当にがまんできないよ。

context_sentences.en: You are a loser and really creepy!
context_sentences.ja: この負け犬め！キモいんだよ！

data.meaning_mnemonic: With <vocabulary>待ち</vocabulary> you know you're waiting, but what's a <vocabulary>ぼうけ</vocabulary>? Turns out it's the long version of <ja>ボケ</ja> which means idiot. Basically, in this case you're a waiting idiot. Why? because you were <vocabulary>stood up</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for <ja>待ち</ja> comes right from <ja>待つ</ja>. You know the drill by now.

context_sentences.en: I waited in vain for a response.
context_sentences.ja: 返事を待っていましたが、待ちぼうけを食らいました。

context_sentences.en: Thanks to that, I was stood up for about an hour at a desolate station.
context_sentences.ja: おかげで、さびれたえきで、一時間も待ちぼうけをする羽目になったよ。

context_sentences.en: Could you please tell him tomorrow’s conference has been cancelled so he won’t feel like he’s been stood up?
context_sentences.ja: 彼が待ちぼうけを食らったと思わないように、明日の会議が中止になったことを伝えてあげてくれるかな？

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <ja>勝つ</ja> by now, which means "to win." This is a nouny version of that. So, what's the noun version of "to win?" It's <vocabulary>a win</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>victory</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>勝つ</ja>. So as long as you have some understanding of that reading, you should be able to read this one as well.

context_sentences.en: Koichi won the belly dancing competition hands down.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチはベリーダンス対決でボロ勝ちした。

context_sentences.en: Japan's national snow ball fighting team made a comeback to clinch the victory.
context_sentences.ja: 雪合せん日本代表はぎゃく転勝ちをおさめた。

context_sentences.en: It’s first come, first served. Let’s get a move on! I really want the Fugu keychain. I don’t want to miss out on this chance.
context_sentences.ja: 早い者勝ちなんだだから、急ごうよ！あのフグのキーホルダーすごく欲しいんだよね！この機会を逃したくないんだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <ja>決定</ja> is a "decision." So, when you add <ja>する</ja> to it you're making it a verb, meaning this word means <vocabulary>to decide</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>決定</ja> with <ja>する</ja> added. Make sure you know <ja>決定</ja> and you'll know this word as well.

context_sentences.en: Once they've decided on a name for Koichi's baby I'll let you know right away.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチの赤ちゃんの名前が決定したら、すぐにお知らせしますね。

context_sentences.en: Koichi has the right to decide his employee's salaries.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは、じゅう業いんのきゅうりょうを決定するけん利を持っている。

context_sentences.en: ROFL! This TV show is hilarious, man. I’ve decided that this is now my new favorite show.
context_sentences.ja: クソワロタwwwこのテレビ番組クソほど面白いじゃねーかよ。俺の一番好きな番組に決定したわ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>exit</kanji> your house and you <kanji>meet</kanji> someone. You didn’t mean to meet them, but it happened anyway. That’s why this word means <vocabulary>to meet by chance</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading is that of the word <ja>出る</ja> and the word <ja>会う</ja>, both of which you've hopefully seen. The <ja>出</ja> portion may be confusing, but you can usually assume that if one part of the word is kun'yomi / vocab reading, the other part is too, which is why <ja>出</ja> uses the vocab reading.

Oh by the way, this word can be written like this too: <ja>出合う</ja>. It’s not as common, but you may come across it every now and then, so it’s good to know!

context_sentences.en: It looks like we happened to run into each other a little too early.
context_sentences.ja: わたしたち、ちょっと出会うのが早すぎたみたいね。

context_sentences.en: Last night, I met a guy who's looking for no strings attached fun at a club and I know I shouldn't be into him, but he was really my type.
context_sentences.ja: きのうの夜、クラブで、れんあいかんじょうぬきでただ楽しみたいっていう男に出会ってさ、ハマっちゃいけないのは分かってるけど、めちゃくちゃタイプだったんだよね。

context_sentences.en: "Are you seeing anyone now, Nicole?" "Yes, I’ve been seeing Eric for a year." "Wow, where did you guys meet?"
context_sentences.ja: 「ニコールって、今、付き合っている人いるの？」「ええ。エリックと1年間付き合っているわ。」「そうなんだ！彼とは、どこで出会ったの？」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You learned the word <ja>苦しい</ja> (hopefully) in level 9. That word means suffering. So, if you make that into a verb version, you have <vocabulary>to suffer</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>苦しい</ja>, so as long as you're on top of that word, this word should be readable for you as well.

context_sentences.en: It’s really hard to understand Tofugu's way of thinking.
context_sentences.ja: トーフグの考え方は、理かいに苦しみます。

context_sentences.en: I'm struggling under intense pressure from Koichi, who aided and abetted me in a crime.
context_sentences.ja: はんざいに手をそめるようそそのかしてくるコウイチからの強れつなプレッシャーに苦しんでいます。

context_sentences.en: I’m just thinking about your new wife at home. Okay? Do you really want to make her suffer from your death for the rest of her life? So, don’t commit suicide.
context_sentences.ja: オレは家にいるおまえの新妻のことを考えて言ってるだけだよ。分かるか？彼女がお前の死で一生苦しむことになっても、本当にいいのか？だから、自殺なんてするなって。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>attach</kanji> your <kanji>energy</kanji> (imagine someone suddenly looking up at something, attaching their energy to it), they have noticed or realized something. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to realize</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to notice</vocabulary>. 

Don't confuse this with <ja>気を付けて</ja> which is similar in that it has all the same kanji. It's just used a little different. Try to remember the difference before moving on.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the <ja>気</ja> kanji (which you know) and the word <ja>付く</ja> which you should know by now. Combine these together and you have the ability to read this word. Take note that the <ja>付く</ja> part is rendaku'd, though, so it is a tiny bit different.

context_sentences.en: Don't pretend like you didn't notice.
context_sentences.ja: 気付かないふりはしないでください。

context_sentences.en: I think I realized my feeling for Koichiko three days after we met.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチ子へのおもいに気付いたのはかの女と出会って三日目のことだったと思います。

context_sentences.en: I can’t believe you gave me your ice cream. I didn’t realize that you were so kind until now.
context_sentences.ja: あんたが私にアイスクリームをくれるなんて、本当に信じられないよ。あんたがそんなに優しいなんて今まで気付かなかったわ！

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know the words <ja>見る</ja> and <ja>送る</ja> by now, hopefully. Here you're "seeing" the "sending." You're seeing someone off, so this verb is <vocabulary>to see off</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the vocab words <ja>見る</ja> and <ja>送る</ja>. Make sure you know those and you'll know this word's reading as well.

context_sentences.en: I'll go to the airport to see you guys off.
context_sentences.ja: 空こうまで見送るよ。

context_sentences.en: I wonder which is harder, being the person who sees someone off or being one who is seen off by someone.
context_sentences.ja: 見送る方と見送られる方って、どっちの方がつらいんだろうね。

context_sentences.en: Koichi burst into tears after seeing them off.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは、彼らを見送った後、どっと涙の雨を流した。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know the single word <ja>時</ja>, right? It means <kanji>time</kanji>. This is that twice. So you have one time, and you have another time. They are separate. Things don't happen in every of these times you have. They happen <vocabulary>sometimes</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the vocab word <ja>時</ja> twice, with the second one getting rendaku'd.

context_sentences.en: Sometimes I read Tofugu articles in a restaurant on the top floor of the Tofugu hotel.
context_sentences.ja: 私は時々トーフグホテルの最上階のレストランでトーフグの記事を読みます。

context_sentences.en: At the beach, sometimes a pleasant breeze would gently caress my cheek.
context_sentences.ja: はま辺では、時々、そよ風がわたしのほほをやさしくなでていった。

context_sentences.en: Tofugu gets into trouble with its customers at times. One time it even led to a fist fight that ended in a death, so you should be careful with them, really.
context_sentences.ja: トーフグって、時々お客さんともめるんだよね。あるトラブルが、死人を出すなぐり合いのけんかになったこともあるから、ほんと、気を付けた方がいいよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Imagine someone <kanji>accept</kanji>ing something and then <kanji>attach</kanji>ing something. This person is a <vocabulary>receptionist</vocabulary>, because they are accepting the call, writing down the information, and then attaching said information to a sticky note for you to read. You say, "No, I'm not available."
data.reading_mnemonic: For this reading you have to think back to the verb words that get used with this kanji, namely <ja>受ける</ja> and <ja>付ける</ja>. Then just drop off the <ja>る</ja>s and put them together. <ja>受</ja> becomes <ja>うけ</ja> and <ja>付</ja> becomes <ja>つけ</ja> and you're left with <ja>うけつけ</ja>. This is what's called a compound word. And now you know it. Nice!

context_sentences.en: I heard that receptionist lady has a big corn on her left foot.
context_sentences.ja: あの受付の女せい、左足に大きな魚の目があるらしいよ。

context_sentences.en: Arnold Schwarzenegger will be Tofugu's receptionist starting tomorrow.
context_sentences.ja: 明日から、シュワちゃんがトーフグの受付をしてくれます。

context_sentences.en: Huh? I don’t know. Didn't someone at reception explain it to you?
context_sentences.ja: え？知らない。受付で聞いてない？

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <ja>買う</ja> by now and know it means "to buy." So, <ja>買い</ja> is going to be similar to that. Add that to <kanji>thing</kanji> and you have a "buying things" sort of word. What does "buying things" describe? It describes <vocabulary>shopping</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Also, you can use the reading for <ja>買う</ja> to help you with <ja>買い</ja> as well. <ja>物</ja> is just <ja>もの</ja>, like you learned.

context_sentences.en: I’m shopping at the grocery store.
context_sentences.ja: わたしはスーパーで買い物をしています。

context_sentences.en: As for shopping, I usually just do it online.
context_sentences.ja: 買い物はいつもネットショッピングですませています。

context_sentences.en: We’re going Christmas shopping today! I’m so excited!
context_sentences.ja: 今日はクリスマスの買い物に行くの！すごくワクワクするわ！

data.meaning_mnemonic: A "suffering hand" is a little misleading. Think more in terms of the words <ja>苦い</ja> (bitter) and <ja>手</ja> (person... remember how that happens sometimes?). Now think of this word like you're bitter about having to work with someone. Why? Because they are extremely <vocabulary>hard to deal with</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is that of <ja>苦い</ja> (<ja>にがい</ja>) plus regular old <ja>手</ja> (<ja>て</ja>). Remember, this is your bitter person, the person who's "hard to deal with." So, it uses the strange <ja>にがい</ja> reading.

context_sentences.en: Silence is hard to deal with.
context_sentences.ja: ちんもくが苦手です。

context_sentences.en: "What is your weak point, Koichi?" "I'm not good at singing."
context_sentences.ja: 「コウイチが苦手なことって何ですか？」「ぼくは歌が苦手です。」

context_sentences.en: You and I used to be inseparable, but you know, now it’s like… things are different. Honestly, I feel uncomfortable with you.
context_sentences.ja: 俺とお前は昔は切っても切れない仲だっただろ。でもさ、 ほら、今は昔とは違うというか何というか、えっと…正直いって、お前のこと苦手なんだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>like</kanji> <kanji>alcohol</kanji> a lot, you're probably a heavy <vocabulary>drinker</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading here as you can probably guess from the hiragana sticking out on the end. You should know the readings of these as separate words already (<ja>酒</ja> and <ja>好き</ja>) which means all you need to pay attention to is the rendaku of <ja>すき</ja> to <ja>ずき</ja>.

context_sentences.en: My boyfriend is a drinker, so I'm worried.
context_sentences.ja: かれ氏は酒好きなんで、心配なんですよね。

context_sentences.en: That alcoholic is drinking in the morning again today.
context_sentences.ja: あの酒好き、今日も朝から引っかけてやがるぜ。

context_sentences.en: My wife is a drinker and I’m worried about her becoming an alcoholic.
context_sentences.ja: 私の妻は酒好きなので、アル中にならないか心配だ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen <ja>飲む</ja>, so you know this has to do with <kanji>drink</kanji>ing <kanji>alcohol</kanji>. Someone who's known as someone who drinks alcohol is an <vocabulary>alcoholic</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the vocab words <ja>お酒</ja> and <ja>飲む</ja> combined together into one. You can guess it's a kun'yomi reading because of the <ja>み</ja> on the end of <ja>飲</ja>, which should make you think back to vocab words that use these kanji and the kun'yomi readings. If you can do that, you can read this word (and many others, probably!).

context_sentences.en: He likes dried cuttlefish, even though he is a kid, eh? He could be a boozer in the future.
context_sentences.ja: 子どものくせにスルメがすきだなんて、こりゃぁこの子はしょう来酒飲みになるねぇ。

context_sentences.en: Koichi likes drinking, but he isn't like an alcoholic.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチはお酒は好きだけど、酒飲みってほどじゃあないですよ。

context_sentences.en: He’s a heavy drinker but he doesn’t like red wine.
context_sentences.ja: 彼は大酒飲みだが、赤ワインが苦手だ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>chirp</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is a sound an animal makes. Sure, it works for birds (which chirp), but it also works with most other animals as well. So, we call this an <vocabulary>animal cry</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are those that you learned with the kanji. <ja>声</ja> gets changed to <ja>ごえ</ja>, though, so take note of that in your head. Perhaps you can imagine an animal that does a "GOEEEEE" cry.

context_sentences.en: Have you ever heard what a giraffe sounds like?
context_sentences.ja: きりんの鳴き声を聞いたことがありますか。

context_sentences.en: I thought I heard Koichi outside, but it was a little bird's chirps.
context_sentences.ja: 外からコウイチの声が聞こえると思ったら、小鳥の鳴き声だった。

context_sentences.en: I hear a puppy barking under the vending machine.
context_sentences.ja: 自動販売機の下から子犬の鳴き声が聞こえるんです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>thing</kanji> you <kanji>drink</kanji> is a <vocabulary>beverage</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: These are both the kun'yomi readings. You've learned them already, so you already know how to read this word!

context_sentences.en: What's the drink that Koichi's drinking?
context_sentences.ja: コウイチの飲んでいる飲み物は何ですか？

context_sentences.en: Beverages containing alcohol shouldn't be drunk during pregnancy.
context_sentences.ja: にんしん中は、アルコールをふくんだ飲み物は飲んではいけない。

context_sentences.en: "Would you like something cold to drink?" "Well then, could I have two cartons of milk?"
context_sentences.ja: 「何か冷たい飲み物はいかがですか？」「それでは、牛乳パックを二本頂けますか？」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen <ja>聞く</ja> by now hopefully. This is similar, but instead of meaning "to hear" it means <vocabulary>hearable</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to be audible</vocabulary>). Just think about that <ja>こえ</ja> hanging off there as the voice you can hear.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>聞く</ja>, so if you know the reading of that word, you can apply it here.

context_sentences.en: If you could hear me, you should've said something!
context_sentences.ja: 聞こえたんだったら、ちゃんと返事してよ！

context_sentences.en: You heard my fart, didn't you?
context_sentences.ja: オナラ、聞こえちゃったよね？

context_sentences.en: I understand it sounds harsh, but I’m up to my neck in lame excuses.
context_sentences.ja: きつい言い方に聞こえることは分かってるんだけど、つまらない言い訳はしたくないの。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>action</kanji>s and <kanji>things</kanji> you have to <ja>心配</ja> about are your <vocabulary>cares</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>worries</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading of <ja>心配</ja> (which you've hopefully gotten down okay by now) and <ja>事</ja> using the (<ja>こと</ja>) reading. It is rendaku'd, as well, so beware of the <ja>ごと</ja> (just another <ja>心配事</ja>, ammiright?).

context_sentences.en: Thank you for laughing my cares away.
context_sentences.ja: 心配事をわらいとばしてくれてありがとう。

context_sentences.en: Apparently he's got some worries.
context_sentences.ja: なんだか心配事があるみたいだよ。

context_sentences.en: My biggest worry is volcanic ash falling over the city.
context_sentences.ja: 私の一番の心配事は、町に降り落ちる火山灰です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>sound</kanji> <kanji>read</kanji>ing. What could this be...? Wait a sec, think to Japanese and kanji. What's the reading that uses sounds from another place, specifically China? That's the <vocabulary>Chinese reading</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>on'yomi</vocabulary>. Sounds familiar?
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for <ja>音</ja> is the <ja>音読み</ja>. <ja>読み</ja> uses the kun'yomi, though, strangely. Way to mess up the one word that should be all on'yomi, Japan. Way. To. Go.

context_sentences.en: What was the on'yomi for this kanji again?
context_sentences.ja: この漢字の音読みって何だっけ？

context_sentences.en: We usually read place names that we see for the first time with on'yomi.
context_sentences.ja: 初めて見た地名はふ通は音読みしちゃうよね。

context_sentences.en: What’s the difference between the Chinese reading and the Japanese reading in the Japanese language?
context_sentences.ja: 日本語の音読みと訓読みの違いは何ですか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: To do a <kanji>concept</kanji> of an <kanji>image</kanji> (in your mind) would require you <vocabulary>to imagine</vocabulary> it, because it's just a concept and not real.
