context_sentences.ja: きのう、ニュースを見ていたら、ビエトが思想犯としてたいほされたニュースが出て本当にびっくりしたよ。

context_sentences.en: Koichi is the founder of Tofugu and one of the great modern Japanese thinkers.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチはトーフグの創始者であり、近代日本を代表する啓蒙思想家である。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>five</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji>s that you have are what? Sight, sound, taste, touch, and smell (don't count the sixth one where you see dead people). These are <vocabulary>the five senses</vocabulary> that you probably have.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: If you had to lose one of your five senses, which one would you give up and why?
context_sentences.ja: 五感のうちどれか一つを失ってしまうとしたら、どれを選びますか？また、その理由も教えてください。

context_sentences.en: In my dream last night, there was a smell I didn't notice before... do all five senses work in dreams?
context_sentences.ja: さく夜のゆめで、今までにかいだことのないにおいを感じました。五感ってねている間も働いているんでしょうか。

context_sentences.en: Please study Japanese words and verbs related to the five senses, as well as some Japanese vocabulary related to the sixth sense.
context_sentences.ja: 五感に関する日本語の単語と動詞の他に、第六感に関する語彙も学習してください。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you have the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> as someone else, you have <vocabulary>sympathy</vocabulary> for them, because you know how they feel. How kind of you!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I empathize with Koichi's views.
context_sentences.ja: わたしはコウイチの意見に同感ですね。

context_sentences.en: I've never agreed with someone so much.
context_sentences.ja: 今までにこんなに同感したことがないぐらい、思いっきり同感しています。

context_sentences.en: "I hate Fugu." "I feel the same way."
context_sentences.ja: 「私、フグのこと嫌い。」「同感だわ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>飲む</ja> is drink, so this has to do with <kanji>drink</kanji>ing. Also, <ja>会</ja> means <kanji>meet</kanji>, so when you meet to drink you're getting together with others to drink. It's a <vocabulary>drinking party</vocabulary>!
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the <ja>飲む</ja> vocabulary word and the regular kanji reading for <ja>会</ja>. Hopefully you know both of those by now so you can apply them to the reading of this word, too!

context_sentences.en: Drinking parties hosted by Tofugu are so fun!
context_sentences.ja: トーフグ主さいの飲み会はとても楽しいですよ！

context_sentences.en: These days there seems to be an increase in the number of students who are forced to chug drinks at parties and die of acute alcohol poisoning.
context_sentences.ja: 最近、飲み会で一気飲みを強要されて急せいアルコール中どくで死ぼうする学生がふえているようです。

context_sentences.en: My mom says that I can’t go to the drinking party. Your parents are really chill about stuff like alcohol. I’m jealous.
context_sentences.ja: お袋が飲み会には行っちゃダメだって言うんだよね。お前んとこの親がアルコールとかに対して厳しくないの、羨ましいよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <kanji><ja>運転</ja></kanji> has to do with driving, right? And you know that <kanji><ja>手</ja></kanji> often has to do with a person doing something in words like these. So, a person who does driving is what? A <vocabulary>driver</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi, because it's jukugo. You should know the on'yomi reading of <ja>手</ja> by now just by seeing similar word patterns to this one.

context_sentences.en: When I took the taxi, the driver happened to be Tofugu's Koichi.
context_sentences.ja: タクシーに乗ったら運転手がトーフグのコウイチだった。

context_sentences.en: I ended up getting in an argument with the bus driver.
context_sentences.ja: バスの運転手と言い争いになってしまった。

context_sentences.en: The driver seemed okay but his car was totaled in the accident.
context_sentences.ja: 運転手は大丈夫だったみたいだけど、車は事故でめちゃくちゃになっていたよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>leaf</kanji> that <kanji>fall</kanji>s are <vocabulary>fallen leaves</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is a bit strange. You'll have to pull from your knowledge of <ja>落ちる</ja> and use that for the first half. Then, <ja>葉</ja> is rendaku'd to <ja>ば</ja>. Because, when a leaf falls, Scrooge says "BAH! Humbug!" (probably because he's losing money).

context_sentences.en: There was a carpet of fallen leaves that stretched out around us.
context_sentences.ja: 目の前には、落ち葉のじゅうたんが広がっていました。

context_sentences.en: I picked up some fallen leaves and made tempura with them.
context_sentences.ja: 落ち葉をひろって天ぷらにしました。

context_sentences.en: "Look, when it started I was just trying to be nice to Fugu because he was my big sister’s boyfriend. Then, one thing led to another and before I knew it, we were... raking fallen leaves together." "T-Tuna. Why would you do that?" "Salmon, wait. We only did it once. It didn’t mean anything to me."
context_sentences.ja: 「聞いてよ。最初は、お姉ちゃんの彼氏だから、フグと仲良くしようとしてただけだったの。でも、次々にいろんなことが重なって、知らない間に、お…落ち葉を一緒に熊手で集めてたの。」「ツ…ツナったら、なんてことなの。」「サーモン、待って。一度だけよ。それに、私は何とも思わなかったわ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>father</kanji> <kanji>parent</kanji> is your <vocabulary>father</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading here is pretty weird. It's all kun'yomi. My guess is this translates literally to "father parent" (two different words, therefore uses the other readings). You should know the readings of these two separate words, though. It is <ja>父</ja> (<ja>ちち</ja>) and <ja>親</ja> (<ja>おや</ja>).

context_sentences.en: My father is a super weak wrestler.
context_sentences.ja: わたしの父親はへなちょこレスラーです。

context_sentences.en: This morning, I saw my father secretly crying in his room.
context_sentences.ja: 今朝、父親が部屋でこっそり泣いているのを見てしまいました。

context_sentences.en: My father eats his dinner by himself in the alley because everyone in my family hates him.
context_sentences.ja: 家族はみんな父親のこと嫌ってるから、父はいつも一人裏通りで夕飯を食べてるわ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>mother</kanji> <kanji>parent</kanji> is the <vocabulary>mother</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is strange. It's the kun'yomi vocab reading, probably because the literal translation is "mother parent" and therefore consists of a couple words combined together into one concept. So, make sure you know the separate word readings of <ja>母</ja> and <ja>親</ja>. If you do, you should be able to read this too.

context_sentences.en: I want to make up with my mother.
context_sentences.ja: 母親と仲直りがしたい。

context_sentences.en: My mother and her boyfriend ended up breaking up because apparently they had been gradually growing apart.
context_sentences.ja: 母親とそのかれ氏、気持ちがだんだんはなれていっちゃったみたいで、けっきょく別れたんだよね。

context_sentences.en: "I’m sorry but I have to cancel lunch tomorrow. My mother got sick." "It’s no big deal. Let’s meet another time. I hope your mom gets well soon."
context_sentences.ja: 「ごめんなさい。明日のランチ、キャンセルしなくちゃいけなくなったの。母親がちょっと体調崩しちゃって。」 「気にしないで。また今度、会いましょう。それより、お母様、早く良くなるといいわね。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember <ja>一番目</ja>? This is just like that, but with three, making it the <vocabulary>third thing</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>the third</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Use your knowledge of the reading for <ja>一番目</ja> to remember the reading for this word as well.

context_sentences.en: This is probably my third favorite Beatles's song.
context_sentences.ja: この曲、ビートルズの中で三番目くらいにすき。

context_sentences.en: If you are looking for Koichi, he's reading Harry Potter on the third toilet from the left.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチなら左から三番目のトイレでハリーポッターを読んでるよ。

context_sentences.en: Did you know that Japan has the third highest number of inhabited islands in the world, after Indonesia and the Philippines?
context_sentences.ja: 日本の有人島の多さは、インドネシア、フィリピンに次いで、世界で三番目だってこと、知ってた？

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>see</kanji>ing is <kanji>return</kanji>ing on something. This is when you look back at something you've already looked at before. This word means <vocabulary>to look back at</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are just <ja>見</ja> and the vocab word <ja>返る</ja>, combined together. So long as you know both of those you should be able to combine them into the reading for this word.

context_sentences.en: I don't have time to look back on the past.
context_sentences.ja: か去を見返ってるひまはないんだよ。

context_sentences.en: The figure of the baby looking back at me is just too cute and totes adorbs.（*´▽｀*）
context_sentences.ja: 赤さまの見返るおすがたがただただかわいすぎてモエまくっておりまする（*´▽｀*）

context_sentences.en: There was a huge crash and I involuntarily looked behind me.
context_sentences.ja: ガシャーンと大きな音がして、私は思わず後ろを見返った。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>way</kanji> of <kanji>speak</kanji>ing is your <vocabulary>way of speaking</vocabulary> (or it could be your <vocabulary>speaking style</vocabulary>). This is how someone talks. Some people have an interesting speaking style, after all.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from <ja>話す</ja> and <ja>方</ja>. By now you should have seen these words separately and should be able to read this word too.

context_sentences.en: The way he talks makes me really annoyed.
context_sentences.ja: 話し方が本当にイライラするのよね。

context_sentences.en: Koichi's style of conversation is very cultured, eh?
context_sentences.ja: コウイチの話し方って、かなりしぶいよね。

context_sentences.en: Wow! The way you talk sounds just like a native Japanese person.
context_sentences.ja: うわぁ！君の話し方、まるで母国語が日本語の人みたいだね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Do you remember the word <ja>転がる</ja>? This is kind of similar, instead of rolling, this is more for when something falls and hits the ground. It means <vocabulary>to fall over</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fall down</vocabulary>. Just imagine someone falling off a chair face first into the dirt and making a <ja>ぶ</ja> sound.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>転がる</ja>. Hopefully you know that one well enough to associate it with this one, meaning you can read them both.

context_sentences.en: It was funny that the player fell over after hitting a game-ending home run.
context_sentences.ja: サヨナラホームランを打った後であのせん手が転んだのはおも白かったね。

context_sentences.en: Today, Koichi didn't cry even though he fell down for the first time in a long time.
context_sentences.ja: 今日のコウイチは、久しぶりに転んでもなかなかった。

context_sentences.en: Koichi had almost fallen to the ground, but Viet, who was wearing a Superman costume, saved him.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチはもう少しで地面に転ぶところだったが、スーパーマンのコスプレをしたビエトに助けられた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: I bet you remember <ja>集める</ja> which means "to collect." This is similar to that, except you're not doing the action of collecting, it's just happening. Instead of "to collect" it's <vocabulary>to come together</vocabulary>. You can remember this because a herd of <reading>Maru</reading>s (the cat) will come together into one place if they sense a box there.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>集める</ja> so if you know that word you'll know how to read this word as well.

context_sentences.en: This much money was gathered by crowdfunding.
context_sentences.ja: クラウドファンディングで、こんなにたくさんのお金が集まりました。

context_sentences.en: The company retreat gives all the workers a chance to come together.
context_sentences.ja: 社員旅行は、全社員が集まるいいき会になります。

context_sentences.en: Look! A group of miscreants are gathering over there!
context_sentences.ja: 見て！あそこにヤンキーたちがたくさん集まってるよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen how <ja>落ちる</ja> means "to fall down." Now you're doing the action of "falling something down," aka you're dropping it. You can remember this because you kind of <reading>toss</reading> (<ja>とす</ja>) something and it drops to the ground, making this word mean <vocabulary>to drop something</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>落ちる</ja>. So long as you know that word you can apply that reading over here, too.

context_sentences.en: This morning, I accidentally dropped a raw egg under Koichi's desk.
context_sentences.ja: 今朝、コウイチのデスクの下に生たまごを落としてしまいました。

context_sentences.en: You should immediately stop doing things that will make people lose faith in you.
context_sentences.ja: そんなしん用を落とすようなことは今すぐ止めた方がいいよ。

context_sentences.en: "Today I bought a book called 'How to Make a Man Fall In Love With You,' but I lost it somewhere on the way back home." "Aww. That’s too bad, but don’t be too disappointed. Your day will come."
context_sentences.ja: 「今日、『男を落とす方法』っていう本を買ったんだけど、帰り道にどこかで落としちゃったみたいなんだよね。」「ええ〜。それは運が悪かったわね。でも、そんなに肩を落とさないで。そのうち良いことあるわよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: By now you should know that <ja>終わる</ja> means "to end" or "to finish." So what is this noun-version of that word? It would be <vocabulary>the end</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the finish</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>終わる</ja>. So long as you know that word, you can learn this word's reading as well!

context_sentences.en: This is the end.
context_sentences.ja: これで終わりだ。

context_sentences.en: All is well that ends well, right?
context_sentences.ja: 終わり良ければ全て良し、でしょ？

context_sentences.en: Work ends this week and Christmas holidays starts next week! Aww I can't wait for that.
context_sentences.ja: 今週で仕事も終わりで、来週からはクリスマス休暇だー！あー、待ちきれない。

data.meaning_mnemonic: We've seen a few times where <ja>電</ja> refers to a train. They're big deals, after all, and use a ton of electricity. So, the <kanji>end</kanji> train for this word would refer to the <vocabulary>last train</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: What time was the last train?
context_sentences.ja: 終電、何時だっけ？

context_sentences.en: I've gotta go because it's almost time for the last train.
context_sentences.ja: もうすぐ終電だから、そろそろかえらなきゃ。

context_sentences.en: "If you ever miss the last train, you can always call me." "Thanks, I’ll keep that in mind."
context_sentences.ja: 「もし終電に乗り遅れたら、いつでも電話してくれていいよ。」「有難う。覚えておくよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You should know <ja>開ける</ja> by now. This word is similar to that, except it has to do with when things are just open. It's the same thing, though. The meaning is also <vocabulary>to open</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading can come from <ja>開ける</ja>. So if you know the reading of that word (I hope you do!) then you can apply that knowledge here.

context_sentences.en: Your fly is open.
context_sentences.ja: 社会のまどが開いていますよ。

context_sentences.en: What time does this shop open?
context_sentences.ja: このお店は何時に開きますか。

context_sentences.en: "Excuse me. Is the Tofugu Museum open for business tomorrow?" "Yes, but it might be quite busy, so I suggest you get there early." "Okay, thank you."
context_sentences.ja: 「すみません。トーフグ博物館は明日は開いてますか？」「開いてますよ。でも、混雑が予想されるので、早めにお越しになられることをお勧めします。」「分かりました。有難うございます。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>起きる</ja> means "to wake up." This word, however, means <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary>. Think of it this way. When an action "wakes up" in a way it is occurring as well. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary>. Just imagine a <reading>core</reading> (<ja>こる</ja>) of uranium just occurring out of nowhere to help you to remember this word.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji and the same as <ja>起きる</ja> too, meaning you should be able to put together the reading on your own.

context_sentences.en: I never expected something like this would happen.
context_sentences.ja: まさかこんなことが起こるなんて、思ってもみなかったよ。

context_sentences.en: Please calm down and think carefully about what's taken place.
context_sentences.ja: 今起こったことについて、落ち着いてよく考えてみてください。

context_sentences.en: "Hey, do you want to kiss me?" "Absolutely no way would I ever want to kiss you in a million years. That would never happen even if heaven and earth were turned upside down."
context_sentences.ja: 「ねぇ、僕にキスしたい？」「ありえない。100万年経ってもあんたとキスなんて絶対にしたくないから。天地がひっくり返っても、起こりっこないよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>心配</ja> is "a worry." What about the verb version of that? It would be <vocabulary>to worry</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes straight from <ja>心配</ja> so try to make sure you know that word so you can read this word! It's also all jukugo on'yomi reading, too, so you should be able to figure it out regardless.

context_sentences.en: Safety is that company's first priority, so you don't have to be concerned about that.
context_sentences.ja: あの会社は安全第一だから、心配しなくても大丈夫ですよ。

context_sentences.en: If you are anxious about Tofugu's performance, please buy our tenugui.
context_sentences.ja: トーフグの業せきを心配してくれているのであれば、どうか手ぬぐいを買ってください。

context_sentences.en: The snow is falling heavily outside and the roads are getting pretty icy, so I’m worried about being able to drive up the hill to my boyfriend’s house.
context_sentences.ja: 外では雪がしんしんと降っており、地面が凍りだしているので、彼氏の家に行くときに丘を車で登りきれるのかどうか心配しています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>distribute</kanji> your <kanji>heart</kanji> around you, it's like your heart is everywhere at once, but not in your body. You feel frantic, you don't know what to do because your heart is out there. This represents the feeling you have when you have <vocabulary>a worry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>concern</vocabulary>. <ja>心配しないでね！</ja>
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the <ja>ぱい</ja> in <ja>配</ja> got rendaku'd from <ja>はい</ja>, as well.

context_sentences.en: I’m worried because it’s unusual for him to be so down.
context_sentences.ja: かれが元気がないのはめずらしいので心配です。

context_sentences.en: I got worried about whether the ship was heading east or west.
context_sentences.ja: この船の進行方向が西なのか東なのか心配になった。

context_sentences.en: Don’t worry, everything is going to be fine. You can believe what I say.
context_sentences.ja: 心配しないで。すべて上手くいくよ。私の言うことを信じて。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a lot like <ja>鳴く</ja>, which means "to chirp" (or some other animal noise). This has to do with noises too, but not so much animal and more like bells (including telephones). This word means <vocabulary>to ring</vocabulary>. If it helps, think of the <ja>る</ja> as a hint, kind of like the first sound of the word "ring" (<ja>る</ja>). So, <ja>る</ja> = "ring" and it's a verb, so <vocabulary>to ring</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading can come from <ja>鳴く</ja>. So long as you know the reading for that word you can know the reading for this word as well.

context_sentences.en: My stomach growled.
context_sentences.ja: お腹が鳴ってしまった。

context_sentences.en: Somebody's phone is ringing.
context_sentences.ja: だれかの電話が鳴ってるね。

context_sentences.en: Thunder rumbled but it didn’t rain.
context_sentences.ja: 雷が鳴ったが、雨は降らなかった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>song</kanji> so the verb vocab version of this is <vocabulary>to sing</vocabulary>, because you don't "to song," you "to sing."
data.reading_mnemonic: Awesomely, this uses the same reading as the reading for the vocab words <ja>歌</ja>. Just throw the <ja>う</ja> onto the end and you have yourself the reading. So, sing your heart out and learn this word easily. "IIIIiiIIIiiiII WILLL ALLllwaYYYs Loovvve YoOooOOooooOOOO <ja>♬</ja>!"

context_sentences.en: When you sing, you should keep your abs tight.
context_sentences.ja: 歌う時、ふっきんに力を入れるようにするといいよ。

context_sentences.en: I don't like singing in front of people.
context_sentences.ja: 人前で歌うのはすきじゃないんです。

context_sentences.en: "It’s raining outside. I just want to stay in and sing." "I’ll tell you what. Let’s stay in tonight and I’ll make dinner for you if you’ll sing songs for me."
context_sentences.ja: 「外は雨が降ってるね。外出せずに家で歌でも歌いたいな。」「じゃあ、こうしよう。今夜は出かけるのをやめよう。で、私が夕食を作るから、あなたは私のために歌ってよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>hand</kanji> (or person, as you know <ja>手</ja> often refers to a person) that <kanji>win</kanji>s gets to do <vocabulary>as one pleases</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is weird. It's all kun'yomi, which luckily you've seen before, but still strange. I guess when you do <vocabulary>as one pleases</vocabulary> you can read kanji however you want, in this case the kun'yomi readings. Do note that there's a small <ja>っ</ja> in there before, presumably to connect the two readings of the two kanji together.

context_sentences.en: You are so selfish!
context_sentences.ja: ほんと、勝手だよね！

context_sentences.en: Don't say whatever you want.
context_sentences.ja: 勝手なことばっかり言わないでよ！

context_sentences.en: "Salmon! Fugu cheated on you five times. Never trust a guy like that." "I know… but he says he can’t live without me." "Well, suit yourself then!"
context_sentences.ja: 「サーモン！フグは五回も浮気したんだよ。そんな男のこと、信じちゃダメだってば。」「分かってるんだけど、でも、彼、私がいないと生きていけないって言うの。」「じゃあ、もう、勝手にすれば！」

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a time based word (because of the <ja>に</ja>). What is the <kanji>first</kanji> point of time when you are beginning something? That is the <vocabulary>beginning</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning <reading>Haj</reading> (<ja>はじ</ja>). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).

context_sentences.en: To begin, please first slice the beef and then pan fry it.
context_sentences.ja: まず初めに牛肉をスライスして、それからフライパンでいためてください。

context_sentences.en: First of all, please don't improvise.
context_sentences.ja: 初めに言わせてもらいますが、アドリブえんそうはしないでください。

context_sentences.en: R.I.P. Tofugu. At the beginning of this month my favorite Japanese learning site went bankrupt.
context_sentences.ja: Tofuguよ安らかに眠ってくれ。今月初めに、僕の一番好きな日本語学習サイトが倒産しちゃったんだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>初</ja> means "first" This word means <vocabulary>for the first time</vocabulary>. Think of <ja>めて</ja> as "meet." Then think "when we met <vocabulary>for the first time</vocabulary> ____ happened."
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning <reading>Haj</reading> (<ja>はじ</ja>). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).

context_sentences.en: Since the first time we met, President Obama and I have gotten along very well.
context_sentences.ja: 初めてオバマ大とうりょうと会ったしゅんかんから意気投合した。

context_sentences.en: This is my first time dealing with banking and I'm really struggling.
context_sentences.ja: 初めての銀行業むに四苦八苦しています。

context_sentences.en: "Is it possible this is your first time in Japan?" "Yes, it is." "Oh really? How do you like it?” "I really like it!"
context_sentences.ja: 「もしかして、日本はこれが初めて？」「はい。そうなんです。」「そうなんだ。日本はどう？」「かなり気に入ってるわ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Wind</kanji> of the <kanji>Gods</kanji>. These are <vocabulary>divine winds</vocabulary>. More popularly, this is a word known as <vocabulary>Kamikaze</vocabulary>, which became known because of the kamikaze pilots during WWII. This was used before WWII, though, when the entire Mongol fleet was destroyed by a storm, preventing an invasion of Japan. How lucky.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi readings for both, probably because this is two words put together into one. You know the reading of <ja>風</ja> from previous levels, hopefully. Now all you need to do is apply your knowledge of the word <ja>神</ja> to be able to read the rest.

context_sentences.en: Divine winds blow on this shrine.
context_sentences.ja: この神社には神風がふいています。

context_sentences.en: At the end of WWII, the Japanese army used the kamikaze corps to attack the American army.
context_sentences.ja: 第二次世界大戦の末期には日本ぐんは神風とっこうたいを使ってアメリカぐんをこうげきしました。

context_sentences.en: Five years ago, Koichi drove Viet’s troops back from his shores where they were swallowed up by a divine wind.
context_sentences.ja: 五年前、神風が吹き、コウイチはビエトの軍隊を海岸から後退させた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>transmit</kanji> your <kanji>hand</kanji> to something or someone, you're putting out your hand <vocabulary>to help</vocabulary> them or <vocabulary>to assist</vocabulary> them.
data.reading_mnemonic: Both of these are the kun'yomi readings that you learned with the kanji! The thing is, the <ja>た</ja> goes to <ja>だ</ja> for who knows what reason. Perhaps you can ask for someone <vocabulary>to help</vocabulary> you to understand this dumb reading change.

context_sentences.en: Can you give me a hand in cleaning up the fridge?
context_sentences.ja: れいぞうこをかた付けるの、手伝ってくれない？

context_sentences.en: Viet asked me to help him assassinate Koichi because he purchased a 100 million dollar insurance policy for him.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトに、コウイチに一億ドルのほけん金をかけたので、やつを暗殺するのを手伝ってほしいとたのまれたんだ。

context_sentences.en: I’m sorry. I’d like to help but my hands are tied.
context_sentences.ja: ごめんなさい。お手伝いしてあげたいんだけど、私にはどうにもできないんです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>profit</kanji> from the <kanji>left</kanji>, you're probably doing everything on the left. That's your good side. You're probably <vocabulary>left handed</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings, so combine the readings of the words <ja>左</ja> and <ja>利く</ja> together to get the reading of this one. It makes sense since this word is like two words put together.

context_sentences.en: For some reason I'm always attracted to left-handed women.
context_sentences.ja: なぜかいつも左利きの女せいにひかれるんです。

context_sentences.en: I'm buckling down on work for left-handed people.
context_sentences.ja: 左利きの人向けの仕事に力を入れています。

context_sentences.en: "May I ask the purpose of your call?" "I just want to know if you are left handed." "I’m afraid I’m not at liberty to disclose that information."
context_sentences.ja: 「どういったご用件でしょうか？」「あなたが左利きかどうかだけ知りたいんですが。」「あいにくそれはお伝えできないことになっております。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>教育</ja> means "education?" Well, the <ja>育</ja> here is referring to the education word, but this time it's a <kanji>body</kanji> education. What do you call the body education at school? <vocabulary>Physical education</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>PE</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I hated that time in elementary school when we had to do long-distance running in gym.
context_sentences.ja: 小学校の時、体育のマラソンが大きらいでした。

context_sentences.en: Before the next PE class, please clip your fingernails.
context_sentences.ja: 次の体育のじゅ業の前に、つめを切ってきてください。

context_sentences.en: "Do you want to play volleyball with us on Physical Education Day?" "Oh, it’s a national holiday, right? Isn’t it October 10th or something?" "Yes, it’s a holiday, but is not October 10th anymore. Now it’s the second Monday of October because of the Happy Monday system."
context_sentences.ja: 「体育の日に、一緒にバレーボールしない？」「ああ、確か祝日だったよね。十月十日とかだっけ？」「そうそう。祝日。でも、もう十月十日じゃないよ。ハッピー・マンデー制度ができてから、十月の第二月曜日になったんだよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>right</kanji> side of your body is the side you <kanji>profit</kanji> most from. So, you use it a lot more. That's because you're <vocabulary>right handed</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Both kanji use the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, think to the words <ja>右</ja> and <ja>利く</ja> to learn how to read this one. It probably reads like this because it's two separate words come together (right + handed) rather than one word.

context_sentences.en: My son is not right-handed.
context_sentences.ja: わたしの息子は右利きではありません。

context_sentences.en: Although I am left-handed, my mom bought a right-handed baseball glove by mistake.
context_sentences.ja: ぼくは左利きなのに、お母さんが間ちがえて右利きのグローブを買っちゃったんだ。

context_sentences.en: I really liked her but I was turned off when I found out that she was right handed. I don’t know why.
context_sentences.ja: 彼女のこと、すごく好きだったんだけど、右利きだって分かってから冷めちゃったんだよね。どうしてかは分からないけど。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>好き</ja> is "like." Although <ja>好き</ja> is kind of like a verb already, this is definitely a verb. It can be <vocabulary>to be fond of</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to like</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is a strange one, different from anything you've learned, kanji on'yomi or vocab kun'yomi. The reading is <ja>この</ja>, so think of this. What is it that you're particularly fond of? Getting a <reading>cone</reading> (<ja>この</ja>) with your ice cream (which you're also fond of, who isn't?). Think of all the different cones you can get: waffle cones, sugar cones, oreo cones, yum!

context_sentences.en: This Japanese sake is what my heavy drinker of a father liked when he was alive.
context_sentences.ja: この日本酒は、大変酒好きだった私の父が生前に好んで飲んでいたものです。

context_sentences.en: Koichi likes eating black garlic.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは、黒ニンニクを好んで食べます。

context_sentences.en: I’m sorry, Mr. Koichi. Whether you like it or not, your secrets might get revealed.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチさん、申し訳ありませんが、好むと好まざるとに関わらず、あなたの秘密は暴露されてしまうかもしれません。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is similar to <ja>育つ</ja>, except now you're doing the raising of someone. This word means <vocabulary>to bring up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary>. You can remember this because of the <ja>てる</ja>. Your version of bringing a child up involves <reading>tear</reading>ing (<ja>てる</ja>) all their clothes to make them look poor so they can get the cheaper lunch at school. You're rich because of all the tax breaks you get from all the children you're raising, but you could always use more money to fuel your StarCraft addiction (we've all been there).
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>育つ</ja>. So long as you know that one, you know how to read this one as well.

context_sentences.en: Viet and Koichi love growing vegetables in their office.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトとコウイチは、オフィスで野さいを育てるのが大好きです。

context_sentences.en: Could you raise this puppy instead? I would love to do it, but I need to relocate to Neptune next month.
context_sentences.ja: この子犬をわたしの代わりに育ててくれませんか。わたしが育てたいんですが、来月から海王星に転きんになってしまったんです。

context_sentences.en: What did you raise as a class when you were in elementary school? Our class was raising tadpoles, hamsters, and eggplants, but all of the hamsters ran away and got eaten by cats.
context_sentences.ja: 小学校の時、クラスで何を育ててた？うちのクラスはおたまじゃくしとハムスターとなすを育ててたんだけど、ハムスターはみんな逃げてねこに食べられちゃった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>follow</kanji> then <kanji>attach</kanji> yourself to the thing you're following. You have now caught up! This verb is <vocabulary>to catch up</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, but you can also just notice that this word includes <ja>追う</ja> and <ja>付く</ja> combined.

context_sentences.en: We took a car and less than five minutes later we overtook Koichi who had departed for Seattle on foot on the previous day.
context_sentences.ja: 前日にシアトルまでと歩で出発したコウイチに車で五分もかからず追い付きました。

context_sentences.en: If you can catch up to Kristen in the hundred meter dash, you can compete in the Olympics.
context_sentences.ja: 100メートル走でクリステンに追い付くことができたらオリンピックに出られるよ。

context_sentences.en: Tofugu’s coloring book was so popular that production couldn’t keep up with demand.
context_sentences.ja: Tofuguの塗り絵は人気すぎて、生産が需要に追い付かなかった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is the verb version of the vocab word <vocabulary><ja>戦い</ja></vocabulary>, which I'm hoping you learned earlier. The verb version of course means <vocabulary>to fight</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to battle</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>戦い</ja> a word you've hopefully seen by now. Associate these words together in your mind and you'll be able to read them so long as you know the other one.

context_sentences.en: Japan and America fought in WWII.
context_sentences.ja: 第二次世界大戦で日本とアメリカは戦いました。

context_sentences.en: We battle against this gigantic monster called kanji every day so we can get good at Japanese.
context_sentences.ja: わたしたちは日本語が上手くなるために、毎日このかん字というきょ大な化け物と戦っているんです。

context_sentences.en: Kendo is normally a one-on-one martial art, but 5 years ago Koichi had to fight against two guys at the same time.
context_sentences.ja: 剣道は通常、一対一で戦う武道だが、コウイチは五年前、二人の男を同時に相手にしなくてはいけなかった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>追う</ja> is "to chase." So, you're chasing something or someone, or something similar. Just think of the <ja>かける</ja> as you being all "cocky" about it. You're not just chasing this person, you're following them too. So, this word is <vocabulary>to follow</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to stalk</vocabulary>. Scary!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>追う</ja> as well as the kanji reading you learned too.

context_sentences.en: Ms. Tanaka likes Mr. Yamada a lot, so she chases him every day.
context_sentences.ja: 田中さんは山田さんのことが大すきで、毎日追いかけています。

context_sentences.en: OMG! Koichi left for Japan without his passport. Can you run after him and give him this passport?
context_sentences.ja: 大へんだ！コウイチったらパスポートを持たずに日本へ出発してしまったよ。今すぐ追いかけてこのパスポートをわたしてあげてくれない？

context_sentences.en: I saw Fugu following a pod of killer whales.
context_sentences.ja: シャチの群れを追いかけてるフグを見たよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You hopefully have seen the word <ja>注文</ja> (order, request). This is just the verb version: <vocabulary>to order</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>to request</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you know the reading of <ja>注文</ja> you should be able to read this one too. Also, it's just all jukugo on'yomi readings, so you should be able to read it anyways.

context_sentences.en: I ordered wrapping paper covered in silver glitter.
context_sentences.ja: 銀色のラメの入ったラッピングペーパーを注文しました。

context_sentences.en: I ordered Koichi's used briefs on Amazon by mistake.
context_sentences.ja: アマゾンで、間ちがえてコウイチの使用ずみブリーフを注文してしまった。

context_sentences.en: We could eat out or order takeout. I don’t mind one way or the other.
context_sentences.ja: 外食でも、お持ち帰りで注文しても、僕はどちらでも構わないよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <ja>好き</ja> by now, which is "to like." So, what happens when you have a <ja>大</ja> (big) like? You <vocabulary>really like</vocabulary> something.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>好き</ja> which you've hopefully seen. Then, <ja>大</ja> is the reading you learned with the kanji.

context_sentences.en: I love my boyfriend's habit of fidgeting with his bangs.
context_sentences.ja: かれしが前がみをいじる仕草が大好きです。

context_sentences.en: No matter what he says, Fugu still likes WaniKani a lot.
context_sentences.ja: なんだかんだ言っても、フグはワニカニのことが大好きなんですよ。

context_sentences.en: You’re kind of goofy and that makes you fun to hang out with. I really like you.
context_sentences.ja: 天然ボケで、一緒にいていつも楽しいなって思うんだ。俺、お前のこと大好きだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something is transmitted. No direct object here. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to be transmitted</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as <ja>伝える</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Various legends of Viet before working for Tofugu have been told to the employees.
context_sentences.ja: トーフグに入社する前のビエトの様々な伝せつが社員に伝わっています。

context_sentences.en: Even though you can't speak Japanese well, if you try to speak with your heart, people will understand.
context_sentences.ja: 日本語が上手に話せなくても心で話せばきっと相手に伝わりますよ。

context_sentences.en: A message about how the Tofugu ninjas crept towards the castle during the night was transmitted to Shogun Koichi.
context_sentences.ja: 忍者トーフグ組が夜に城へ忍び寄ったということが、コウイチ将軍に伝わった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>release</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be released</vocabulary>. You can differentiate this one from <ja>放す</ja> (to release) by thinking that it's pretty <reading>rare</reading> (<ja>れる</ja>) for you to be released by your arch nemesis. He just let you go, strangely. How rare.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>放す</ja>. As long as you know that word you can apply that reading over here as well.

context_sentences.en: A horse was released from the stable.
context_sentences.ja: 馬が馬小屋から放れました。

context_sentences.en: I worked hard and was finally released from my debts.
context_sentences.ja: 苦労して働いて、ようやくしゃっ金から放れることができました。

context_sentences.en: I thought that I was finally free of having to care for my children but then my 53-year-old wife got pregnant again.
context_sentences.ja: ようやく子どもから手が放れたと思ったんだが、五十三歳の妻がまた妊娠してしまってね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>room</kanji> where you <kanji>join</kanji> other people to <kanji>wait</kanji>. This is a <vocabulary>waiting room</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Remember how you learned <ja>待合</ja> already? Well throw the on'yomi for <ja>室</ja> on the end of that and you have your reading!

context_sentences.en: I'm in the dentist's waiting room now.
context_sentences.ja: 今、歯医者の待合室にいます。

context_sentences.en: There are waiting rooms for tourist groups in airports.
context_sentences.ja: 空港には、団体で旅行するグループのための待合室があります。

context_sentences.en: I read an economics book the other day in the hospital waiting room and it was pretty interesting.
context_sentences.ja: 数日前、病院の待合室で経済についての本を読んだんだけど、結構良かったよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a noun version of the kanji <kanji>feeling</kanji>. What is that? It's a <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary> as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for both on'yomi and kun'yomi of this kanji are the same, actually. So long as you learned the reading that was with the kanji, you can't go wrong. Feel good?

context_sentences.en: That person is nasty, isn't she?
context_sentences.ja: あの人感じ悪いよね。

context_sentences.en: When I went to the office yesterday, I didn't get the impression that Koichiko was pregnant.
context_sentences.ja: きのうオフィスに行った時にはコウイチ子がにんしんしている感じはしませんでしたよ。

context_sentences.en: What’s it feel like to be a company president, Mr. Koichi?
context_sentences.ja: コウイチさん、社長になるって、どんな感じですか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>feeling</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to feel</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Guess what? Even though this would use the vocab kun'yomi reading, usually, the readings for both on'yomi and kun'yomi on this kanji are the same, meaning you can read this word no matter what. Feeling better now?

context_sentences.en: Don't look at it, feel it with your heart.
context_sentences.ja: 見るのではなく、心で感じてください。

context_sentences.en: Due to the rising power of WaniKani, Tofugu feels that it's been losing its place within the company.
context_sentences.ja: ワニカニの台頭により、トーフグは会社に自分のい場所がなくなっていると感じている。

context_sentences.en: I feel like my older brother has been giving me the cold shoulder recently.
context_sentences.ja: 最近兄に冷たくされていると感じます。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know this is a verb from the <ja>する</ja>. Your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s have been <kanji>move</kanji>d. So, when your feelings have been moved, you are emotionally moved. This word is <vocabulary>to be emotionally moved</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>to be moving</vocabulary>. Just be sure to know this has to do with emotions.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: It was so moving, I can't stop crying.
context_sentences.ja: 感動してなみだが止まりません。

context_sentences.en: I heard the secret story of how Tofugu was established and was really moved.
context_sentences.ja: トーフグのせつ立ひ話を聞いて、とても感動しました。

context_sentences.en: Oh my God! I just made the best Japanese learning material in the history of mankind! Everyone will be really excited!
context_sentences.ja: なんてこった！今までの人類の歴史上で最高の日本語学習教材を作っちまったぜ！みんなマジで感動するだろうな！

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s are in your <kanji>heart</kanji>. When your feelings are in your heart they are pure feelings. You can be happy for people and feel <vocabulary>admiration</vocabulary> for their successes. This is a great feeling to have in your heart.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: You have such an admirable child.
context_sentences.ja: 感心なお子さんですね。

context_sentences.en: You earned my admiration by cleaning your room every single day.
context_sentences.ja: 毎日休まずに部屋をそうじするなんて、感心、感心。

context_sentences.en: Katie earned the admiration of her co-workers with her hard work and attention to detail.
context_sentences.ja: ケイティは、真面目で熱心な働きと細かい気配りで、同僚たちを感心させた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you take your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s and <kanji>concept</kanji>ualize them, you come up with your impressions and thoughts on the subject. That's why this word is <vocabulary>thoughts</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>impressions</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Michael's daily routine is to tell all of his colleagues his thoughts on the anime he watched on the previous day.
context_sentences.ja: マイケルの日かは、毎朝同りょう全員に前日に見たアニメの感想を話すことです。

context_sentences.en: One of my shortcomings as a person who dislikes literature is that all I can say is "it was good" when I am asked for my impressions on the novels I've read.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>reflect</kanji>. The verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be reflected</vocabulary>. You're not doing the reflecting directly. You can remember this by thinking how rude (<ja>る</ja>) it is that someone's reflecting your image using a mirror for everyone outside the dressing room to see.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Your reflection is getting reflected onto the mirror. You don't like it, it doesn't look like you. Impostor reflection! You take a hammer and you <ja><reading>打つ</reading></ja> (<ja>うつ</ja>) it as hard as you can, glass flying everywhere. Then some dubstep starts playing from the broken mirror: <ja>うつうつうつうつ</ja>. You're obviously on meth or something.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Self</kanji> <kanji>nature</kanji> is nature itself. That is <vocabulary>nature</vocabulary>, like all those green things and <ja>青葉</ja> outside. Many apologies if someone hundreds of years from now is reading this. It used to be pretty green outside before the robots.

If you call this "natural" then you are using the <ja>な</ja> adjective <ja>自然な</ja>, but I thought it pertinent to add that in here too.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Wait! When it has no dakuten, it is in the form that <vocabulary>nature</vocabulary> intended.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is for when a thing is <kanji>hot</kanji>, making this word <vocabulary>hot thing</vocabulary>. When the weather is hot that's <ja>暑い</ja>. This is when you touch something and you burn yourself.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This has the same reading as <ja>暑い</ja>, so if you've learned that you'll know how to read this word as well. If you haven't run into that word, you've probably run into the kanji <ja>暑</ja> at least. That uses the reading <ja>あつ</ja>. Two similar concepts, but there are two kanji to differentiate, which gets confusing.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When your <kanji>heart</kanji> is <kanji>fever</kanji>ish and hot about something, it is obviously something you have a lot of <vocabulary>enthusiasm</vocabulary> about. If you're not learning, you're not really practicing, are you?

data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You put on the <vocabulary>ring</vocabulary> you found, hoping it will be the one ring to rule them all (invisibility!). Instead, it turns out it's a special <reading>Wa</reading>lken ring, made out of Christopher Walken's bones. It talks up to you, telling you how he kept this ring in his (*ahem*) butt during the war so he could get it to you. First of all, why is this ring talking? Second, why is it talking like Walken. Third, eww, gross, it was in his anus.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a strange one, but in one way it makes sense. Just make sure you're thinking of <ja>手</ja> as the word for "person," kind of like <ja>運転手</ja> or something along those lines. If you do that, you can say "the person that you choose." One situation in which you'd choose a person to do something is in sports. That's why this is a <vocabulary>pro athlete</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sports player</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for <ja>選</ja> is what you'd expect. <ja>手</ja> is the on'yomi reading as it is every once in a while, especially when it has to do with representing a person, so you'll have to remember that. I think you've seen <ja>手</ja> using this reading enough to be able to remember it, though.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a fun one. <kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>silver</kanji> is <vocabulary>mercury</vocabulary>, which makes a lot of sense. Mercury is liquidy like water, but it is all silver like silver. So silver water isn't some new mineral water you can get for $4 at the store, it's <vocabulary>mercury</vocabulary>! Or <vocabulary>quicksilver</vocabulary>, if you prefer.

context_sentences.en: If we go to karaoke, why don't we choose the plan where we can sing as much as we want until the morning?
context_sentences.ja: カラオケに行くなら、朝まで歌い放題のプランにしようよ。

context_sentences.en: If you purchase a lifetime subscription to Textfugu you can study Japanese as much as you want.
context_sentences.ja: もしテキストフグの永久購読権を購読されるのであれば、日本語の学習がし放題ですよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>topic</kanji> that we are <kanji>talk</kanji>ing about is the <vocabulary>topic</vocabulary> that we are talking about. It's the <vocabulary>subject</vocabulary> of our conversation.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: We went to buy the much-talked-about fugu.
context_sentences.ja: 友だちと話題のフグをかいに行きました。

context_sentences.en: When I went to the office the next morning, everyone was talking about Koichi's wedding and his sudden divorce on the following day.
context_sentences.ja: 明くる朝、オフィスに行くと、コウイチのけっこんしきとよく日の電げきりこんの話題で持ちきりだった。

context_sentences.en: I hope you’ve understood so far. All right, now let’s move on to the next topic. Did you know tomatoes are not only native to South America but they’re also Fugu’s favorite vegetable?
context_sentences.ja: ここまでは理解していただけたかと思うのですが。それでは、次の話題に移りましょうか。トマトは、原産地が南米なだけでなく、フグの一番好きな野菜でもあるってことは知っていましたか？

meanings.meaning: If You Would Be So Kind

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a tricky word that doesn't really have a good translation. The best ways I've seen it done in terms of getting a meaning across are <vocabulary>please</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>please help me</vocabulary>. When you say this word you're kind of saying "please help me out and I'm relying on you and you're kind of awesome too." Anyways, <vocabulary>please</vocabulary> is a pretty good way to do it. So, when you see this word you'll notice it has the <kanji>request</kanji> kanji in it. You can guess you're requesting something. What is that thing? It's help (<vocabulary>please help me</vocabulary>) and you're asking very nicely too (<vocabulary>please</vocabulary>).
data.reading_mnemonic: You ask for help by saying <vocabulary>please help me</vocabulary>, and that person does try to help you... but the amount they do for you is so <reading>neg</reading>ligible that it hardly does anything to help you at all. Please try to help me again, this time better?

context_sentences.en: Please God! I want to be fluent in Japanese.
context_sentences.ja: 神様、お願いします！日本語が上手くなりたいんです。

context_sentences.en: If you aren't an active member, please join!
context_sentences.ja: ゆうれい会員でもかまわないので、お願いします。

context_sentences.en: Could I have an aisle seat, please? I hate looking out the window.
context_sentences.ja: 通路側の席をお願いします。窓から外の景色を眺めるのが嫌いなんです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The thing your <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>request</kanji>s is what your heart wants. This is your <vocabulary>heartfelt desire</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: We are touched by Salmon's prayer.
context_sentences.ja: サーモンの心願には心が打たれますね。

context_sentences.en: My heartfelt wish is that the damage caused by the hurricane is less this time.
context_sentences.ja: 今回のハリケーンのひがいが少なくてすむようにというのがわたしの心願です。

context_sentences.en: I bought a charm at the shrine to help fulfill my heart’s desires.
context_sentences.ja: 私はその神社で心願成就の御札を買いました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>foster</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to foster</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're offering <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary> some girl as your own. After the paperwork is over, you can finally say: "<reading>Yah, she now</reading> (<ja>やしな</ja>) is my kid!"

context_sentences.en: Does WaniKani foster Tofugu or does Tofugu foster WaniKani?
context_sentences.ja: ワニカニがトーフグを養っているの？それともトーフグがワニカニを養っているの？

context_sentences.en: We need to keep our eyes peeled so we won't be deceived by Koichi's ninjutsu.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチのにんじゅつにだまされない目を養う必要があります。

context_sentences.en: You should thank your husband sometimes. He has done a good job raising your family, hasn’t he?
context_sentences.ja: たまにはご主人にも感謝しろよ。あいつだって、立派に家族を養ってきたじゃないか。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>foster</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> you bring into your family is your <vocabulary>adopted child</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I heard that station master's kid is actually an adopted child.
context_sentences.ja: あの駅長の子は、どうやら養子らしいです。

context_sentences.en: My friend decided to adopt a child in September.
context_sentences.ja: わたしの友人は九月に養子をむかえいれることにした。

context_sentences.en: I scolded my adopted child because he has such a bad attitude.
context_sentences.ja: 養子の態度が悪いから、叱ってやったんだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>public building</kanji> for taking <kanji>trip</kanji>s is a place you stay when you are taking a trip. Back in the day that would just be an inn or something. Now, this specifies that the inn is a <vocabulary>Japanese inn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Japanese hotel</vocabulary>. A lot of people even just call it by its Japanese name: <vocabulary>ryokan</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: When I travel to Japan, I would like to stay at a Japanese-style hotel.
context_sentences.ja: 日本に旅行に行ったら旅館にとまってみたいです。

context_sentences.en: I'm traveling to Japan next month. Where do you think I should stay: a Japanese-style inn or a hotel?
context_sentences.ja: 来月日本に旅行に行くんだけど、旅館とホテルとどっちにとまった方がいいと思う？

context_sentences.en: "Why are there so many cockroaches in this Japanese inn?" "I think it’s because of all the rain we’ve been getting."
context_sentences.ja: 「なんでこの旅館、こんなにゴキブリが出るの？」「最近雨ばっかり降ってるからじゃない？」

data.meaning_mnemonic: One of the meanings of <ja>本</ja> is <kanji>main</kanji> (which is what we're using here). The <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>public building</kanji> is the <vocabulary>main building</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: The main building has a classroom for pre-school children.
context_sentences.ja: 本館には、ようじ教室の部屋がへいせつされています。

context_sentences.en: We are going to make a book that teaches the history of the main building from scratch.
context_sentences.ja: 本館のれきしをゼロから教える本を作ります。

context_sentences.en: Lots of the people working in the main building of the department store act like someone is forcing them to work, compared to those working at the annex. They have awfully bad attitudes.
context_sentences.ja: あの百貨店の本館で働いている店員は、別館で働いている人たちに比べて、なんか働かされてるって感じだった。愛想がやけに悪いっていうかさ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Usually this refers to a train station in particular, but can be any kind of station.
data.reading_mnemonic: The kanji here uses <ja>えき</ja> as both its on'yomi and kun'yomi, so no worries here. You can go to this station or that station, and both stations will use the same reading as the kanji it comes from.

context_sentences.en: Please get off the train at Shinjuku Station.
context_sentences.ja: 新宿駅でおりて下さい。

context_sentences.en: There is a Tofugu pot sticker shop in front of Ueno Station that Koichi opened with one hundred million yen.
context_sentences.ja: 上野駅の駅の前にはコウイチが一億円かけて出店したトーフグやきぎょうざの店があります。

context_sentences.en: It was nice finally talking to you in person. I never thought I would run into you at a station.
context_sentences.ja: ようやく直接お話することができてよかったです。まさか駅でバッタリお会いするなんて思ってもいませんでしたよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>station</kanji> <kanji>front</kanji> is the <vocabulary>front of station</vocabulary>. This word is great for telling people where you want to meet, by the way.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is like two separate words put together into one, so you can imagine it's the kun'yomi readings. You learned the right reading for <ja>駅</ja> in the kanji, and you should know the vocab word <ja>前</ja> by now. Combine the two together and you have yourself <vocabulary>front of station</vocabulary>.

context_sentences.en: I'm looking for an apartment in front of the station.
context_sentences.ja: 駅前のマンションをさがしています。

context_sentences.en: During the election period, lots of politicians make speeches in front of stations.
context_sentences.ja: せんきょの期間は多くのせいじ家が駅前でスピーチをする。

context_sentences.en: Why did you just send that weird looking selfie taken in front of the station to me?
context_sentences.ja: なんで私に、駅前で撮ったこんな変な自撮り写メを送ってきたの？

data.meaning_mnemonic: A train <kanji>station</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> is someone who works at the train station. They are a <vocabulary>train station employee</vocabulary>. Feel free to ask them if you need help knowing which direction to train in.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I think that train station attendant's irises are larger than most people's.
context_sentences.ja: その駅員の黒目は普通の人よりも大きいと思います。

context_sentences.en: All the station employees here eat bowls of 280 yen kake soba for lunch.
context_sentences.ja: この駅の駅員は、みんなお昼に一杯二百八十円のかけそばを食べる。

context_sentences.en: You couldn’t tell from looking at him, but that station attendant is a really rich guy.
context_sentences.ja: あの駅員、こう見えてすっごくお金持ちなのよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word uses <ja>長</ja> in the same way as <ja>社長</ja>, where it means something like "boss" or "manager." So, this <ja>長</ja> is the boss of the <kanji>station</kanji>, right? What do you call someone like that? You call them the <vocabulary>stationmaster</vocabulary> (that is, unless you want to be thrown to the trains).
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: My favorite idol was selected to be a one-day train station master.
context_sentences.ja: すきなアイドルが一日駅長にえらばれました。

context_sentences.en: Because the stationmaster and Mr. Kawada are best friends, I heard that he secretly gets discount on fares.
context_sentences.ja: 駅長と川田さんは親友だからこっそりと切ぷ代をわり引してもらっているんだって。

context_sentences.en: Oh my God! Did the station master just spit on the train? Did you see that?
context_sentences.ja: うわっ！あの駅長、今電車に唾はかなかったか？お前、見たか？

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This one makes no sense (sorry!). When you <kanji>join</kanji> together with someone at a <kanji>metropolis</kanji>, you do it <vocabulary>at your convenience</vocabulary>. You're important, after all, so you just do what you want and make the other person wait in this giant metropolis while you move along leisurely. Imagine this, and keep thinking "at your convenience" as you walk about.

This word is usually used in a nicer way, though. As in, "do it at your convenience!"
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading for <ja>都</ja> is an exception from what you learned with the kanji. To remember this, just think about someone who does something at their own convenience. They say, I'm going <reading>to go</reading> (<ja>つごう</ja>) where I want, when I want, at my own convenience.

The <ja>合</ja> (<ja>ごう)</ja> part is a reading you know from the kanji, though, so if you can get to "to go" with the mnemonic, you should be able to put two and two together to know that it's a long vowel <ja>ごう</ja>.

context_sentences.en: I'll get in touch with you as soon as possible.
context_sentences.ja: 都合がつき次第、こちらかられんらくします。

context_sentences.en: Depending on the circumstances, Koichi's wedding ceremony may be postponed.
context_sentences.ja: 都合次第では、コウイチのけっこんしきはえん期になるかもしれません。

context_sentences.en: "Which day is convenient for you, Saturday or Sunday?" "It makes no difference to me."
context_sentences.ja: 「土曜日と日曜日、どちらの方が都合がいい？」「どちらでもいいよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen the word <ja>消す</ja>, I hope. This comes from that. You're extinguishing something with <ja>ゴム</ja>. <ja>ゴム</ja> is a word for either gummy or rubbery things. So, this is a gummy thing that extinguishes something. This is an <vocabulary>eraser</vocabulary> that extinguishes pencil markings.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>消す</ja>, so make sure you know that word so you can read this one!

context_sentences.en: I miss Japanese erasers.
context_sentences.ja: 日本の消しゴムがこいしいです。

context_sentences.en: The Tofugu team got one hundred pencils with rubbers on the end for Koichi's birthday present.
context_sentences.ja: トーフグチームは、コウイチのたん生日に、消しゴム付きのえんぴつを百本分プレゼントしました。

context_sentences.en: "I could give you a chance to apologize to me, Koichi." "For what, Viet? For letting you throw me out of Tofugu office?" "It only happened because you stole my eraser! I need an apology!"
context_sentences.ja: 「コウイチ、お前に謝るチャンスをあげてもいいよ。」「何に謝れっていうんだよ、ビエト？ お前が俺をトーフグのオフィスから追放したことに対して謝れってか？」「そもそもお前が俺の消しゴムを盗んだからそうなったんだろ？いいから謝れよ！」

data.meaning_mnemonic: Someone with <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is someone who has <vocabulary>evil intent</vocabulary>. Hopefully you don't have too much <ja>悪気</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading itself has a lot of <ja>悪気</ja> with all the exceptions it has. The <ja>悪</ja> part is read like <ja>悪い</ja>. Then, <ja>気</ja> is rendaku'd. What an evil reading. Just think "what's the most evil reading I can come up with?" when you see this word. Then you should hopefully be able to read it.

context_sentences.en: I know you don't have any evil intent, but please understand that we could get hurt if you say something like that.
context_sentences.ja: 悪気がないのは知ってるけど、そういうことを言われるとこっちもきずつくんだよ？

context_sentences.en: I didn't do it out of malice, but I'm really sorry that I made you feel that way.
context_sentences.ja: 悪気があってしたわけじゃないんですが、けっかてきにそういう風に感じさせてしまう事になって本当にごめんなさい。

context_sentences.en: By the way, how did you get the job without any experience in the first place? No offense, of course.
context_sentences.ja: ところで、そもそも、何の経験もなくて、どうやってその職を得たの？あ、悪気は無いよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen how <ja>登る</ja> means "to climb." So, if you're <kanji>climb</kanji>ing a <kanji>mountain</kanji> what is that? It's <vocabulary>mountain climbing</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from combining <ja>山</ja> and <ja>登る</ja> together to form one word, <ja>山登り</ja>. If you know the readings of those two words you know the reading of this word too.

context_sentences.en: Is mountain climbing your hobby?
context_sentences.ja: 山登りがしゅ味なんですか？

context_sentences.en: I went to climb a mountain with my quiet friend.
context_sentences.ja: ものしずかな友人と、山登りに行ってきました。

context_sentences.en: Both of us have been through a lot, but we had a long talk while climbing a mountain and decided to get back together.
context_sentences.ja: お互い色々あったんだけど、山登りをしながらじっくり話し合ってさ。なんと復縁することになったよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>stream</kanji> <kanji>go</kanji> <kanji>language</kanji>. This is language that goes down the stream with everything else. Imagine this language being carried away quite quickly so everyone standing on the edge of the stream can grab some of this language. This thing streaming down it is a <vocabulary>popular phrase</vocabulary>. Yolo!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Which popular phrase do you think will be chosen for this year's buzzword of the year?
context_sentences.ja: どの流行語が、今年の流行語大賞にえらばれると思う？

context_sentences.en: A lot of new catchphrases are born every year, huh?
context_sentences.ja: 毎年ほんとに色んな流行語が生まれるよね。

context_sentences.en: In the past few years, "meme" has become a popular word on the internet.
context_sentences.ja: ここ数年の間に、「ミーム」はインターネットでの流行語となりました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>流行</ja> refers to a "trend." So, a "trend" <kanji>song</kanji> is a <vocabulary>popular song</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: We say "pop song" these days, so when I hear "popular song," it reminds me of popular songs from the Showa period.
context_sentences.ja: 今時は「流行りの歌」って言うよね。「流行歌」っていうとなんかしょう和の歌よう曲って感じがする。

context_sentences.en: Follow our Twitter for updates on the latest popular songs.
context_sentences.ja: ツイッターでフォローして、最新の流行歌情ほうをチェックしてね。

context_sentences.en: I like finding good music, but not necessarily popular songs.
context_sentences.ja: 私は、流行歌ではないけど良い曲を見つけるのが好きです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>outside</kanji> the <kanji>example</kanji> doesn't follow the rules. It's not what it's supposed to be (the example), it is the <vocabulary>exception</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: All the dishes at this restaurant are delicious without exception.
context_sentences.ja: このレストランの料理は例外なくどれも美味しいです。

context_sentences.en: Except for a few exceptional cases, I haven't actually seen this hospital successfully complete the procedure.
context_sentences.ja: きわめて例外のケースをのぞいて、この病院がその手術に成功したのをほとんど見たことがありません。

context_sentences.en: Koichi usually sleeps in, but Friday is an exception because he has to wear a suit.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチはいつも朝遅くまで寝ていますが、金曜日はスーツを着なくてはいけないので例外です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>example</kanji> is just an <vocabulary>instance</vocabulary> of what you're describing. Just one <vocabulary>example</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: This is just one example.
context_sentences.ja: これはほんの一例にすぎません。

context_sentences.en: As an example, you can't get skinnier by simply eating less rice and potatoes.
context_sentences.ja: 一例としては、ごはんやじゃがいもを食べるりょうをへらしたからといって、やせられるわけではないということがあげられます。

context_sentences.en: After I hired Salmon as secretary, I found out that she was the type of person who has sudden emotional outbursts in the office. For example, she ripped the telephone from her desk and smashed it to pieces, just to name one small incident.
context_sentences.ja: 秘書としてサーモンを迎え入れた後で、彼女が職場で突然感情を爆発させる性格であることが判明したのです。例えば、自分のデスクの電話を引き抜いて、粉々にブチ壊しちゃったりとか、まあ、ほんの一例を挙げればそんな感じです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This has almost the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. Instead of just simply being "example," though, it's <vocabulary>for example</vocabulary>. So, you could start a sentence with this and be all like "<ja>例えば</ja>, I am using <ja>例えば</ja> in a sentence."
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Using all kinds of "<vocabulary>for examples</vocabulary>" like this, you were <reading>taught</reading> (<ja>たと</ja>) many things throughout your life. For example, you were taught about...

context_sentences.en: For example, let's say there was a person who used to be very popular but isn't at all anymore.
context_sentences.ja: 例えば、昔はすごく人気があったけど、今は落ちぶれてしまった人がいたとしましょう。

context_sentences.en: For instance, what do you think Koichi would say when he almost bit his tongue?
context_sentences.ja: 例えば、舌をかみそうになった時、コウイチなら何て言うと思う？

context_sentences.en: Hey, Sakura, why don’t you come over to my house, like, once or twice a week or something?
context_sentences.ja: なぁ、さくらちゃん、例えば、週に一度や二度ぐらい、うちに来ないか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Example</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is a piece of writing that is an example for maybe a word or a kanji or something like that. This is an <vocabulary>example sentence</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I can't come up with a good sample sentence that uses the word "sample sentence."
context_sentences.ja: 例文という語いを使ったいい例文が思いつきません。

context_sentences.en: Please let us know which WaniKani example sentence is your favorite.
context_sentences.ja: ワニカニの例文の中で一番好きな文章を教えてください。

context_sentences.en: For some reason my teacher always uses my name when she makes model sentences.

You have a secret <reading>knock</reading> (<ja>のこ</ja>), though, that you use to find out if it's one of the remaining forces outside or the enemy, broken through. You hear a knock. What is it? Is it your men or theirs? Imagine it out, focusing on the knock conversation that happens between you and the remainder.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a strange word, I'm afraid. You'll have to bear with it. This, when added onto a word, is like adding an "-al" to a word (or a -like to a word). For example, add it onto <ja>日本</ja> (Japan) and you have "Japanese-like," which comes out to "Very Japanese." It's a weird sort of modifying word that really depends on each situation it's in, though <reading>-al</reading> and <reading>-like</reading> often do a decent job. For now, just know this word means these things. We'll start applying it to various words in the future, slowly but surely.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, probably because this is usually added onto other words, making it behave like a jukugo.

data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about what happens when you build something. What are you doing? You're standing it up. How do you say "to stand" in Japanese? <ja><reading>たてる</reading></ja>. That's the reading of this word as well. If you think about it they're similar!

*Yes, I know it's not actually "After Death" but it's so commonly misconceived as such that I put it in there as the definition. You understand the meaning still, right? Anno Domini is also available as a definition too, so don't fret!

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is pretty weird. <ja>計</ja> is all nice and normal, but <ja>時</ja> is <ja>と</ja> for some reason. It probably is coming from the vocab word <ja>時</ja> (<ja>とき</ja>), is my guess. But even if it is, it's shortened, making it a step more complicated. Maybe it's just better to imagine that your <vocabulary>watch</vocabulary> is a walky <reading>talky</reading> (<ja>とけい</ja>) and run with that?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also refers to <vocabulary>cooked rice</vocabulary>, because you gotta eat cooked rice with every meal, so it's basically synonymous with "meal" itself.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're eating a <vocabulary>meal</vocabulary>... MMmm, delicious! What are you eating? Well, it's a <reading>Mesh</reading> (<ja>めし</ja>) net. Taste the mesh net. It tastes terrible. This is a bad meal. Feel it in your mouth. It's weird and meshy.

context_sentences.en: Oh no. I forgot to cook rice.
context_sentences.ja: しまった！飯をたくのをわすれてた。

context_sentences.en: Koichi would rather work for Tofugu than eat.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは三度の飯よりトーフグの仕事をするのが好きです。

context_sentences.en: Those were some really stinky-smelling meals! I never want to go back to prison.
context_sentences.ja: あそこの飯は本当に臭かったぜ。二度と塀の中には戻りたくねえな。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <ja>ご</ja> just makes this word more polite and fancy. When it comes to food, it's nice to be those things. This has the same meaning as the kanji (<kanji>meal</kanji>) making it <vocabulary>meal</vocabulary>, but it also refers to <vocabulary>cooked rice</vocabulary> as well. So, "Come eat your <ja>ご飯</ja>" can be both "come eat your rice" and "come eat your meal." Really, since most Japanese meals come with rice, though, you can see how the overlap happens.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now how about you "<reading>han</reading>d" me another bowl of rice?

context_sentences.en: Recently we haven't been able to get our meal timing right, have we?

context_sentences.en: Damn it! I just spilled my rice.

context_sentences.en: Why is there a big ball of dried-up, cooked rice in Koichi's desk drawer?

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sad</kanji> so the verb form of that is <vocabulary>to be sad</vocabulary>. Boohoo.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you're going <vocabulary>to be sad</vocabulary> about something right now, it will be <reading>kana</reading> (<ja>かな</ja>). Don't use kana when you're trying to learn kanji! You'll be sad forever if you're stuck using kana your whole life, so don't let that habit start now, friend.

context_sentences.en: Animals, as well as humans, are saddened by the deaths of their friends.

context_sentences.en: Don’t be sad. Your Japanese is good enough for now. Just don’t stop learning and you’ll improve little by little.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji means <kanji>connection</kanji>. This is a verb, so one meaning is <vocabulary>to be connected with</vocabulary>. There are many other ways to say this too. This word is a bit full featured. You can say <vocabulary>to be involved with</vocabulary> or even <vocabulary>To Be Affected</vocabulary>. Basically things that have to do with being connected with something else.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who have you gotten involved with this time? The "<reading>Kaw Kaw</reading> (<ja>かか</ja>) Crow Gang" this time? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and stuff... You don't want <vocabulary>to be connected with</vocabulary> them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is like a fancy and humble way of saying <vocabulary>to know</vocabulary>. Sure, the kanji means <kanji>suppose</kanji>, but think of it this way... When you say "I suppose" it's like a humble way of saying "I know." You're not being as direct about it this way, and in Japanese, that makes you more humble and polite. So, that's why <ja>存じる</ja> means <vocabulary>to know</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. If you remember the kanji reading, you'll have no problem remembering this vocabulary reading as well!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cure</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to cure</vocabulary>. Don't get this confused with <ja>治る</ja> which means "to be healed." This particular verb is when you do the curing. How do you know that? Because when you try to heal them, you mess up, and then they try to <reading>sue</reading> (<ja>す</ja>) you.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I need you <vocabulary>to heal</vocabulary> him, and I need you to heal him right <reading>now</reading> (<ja>なお</ja>). NOW NOW NOW! 

This also shares the reading for <ja>直す</ja>, a very similar word you learned previously, which means "to fix." I'm guessing that the Japanese word <ja>なおす</ja> was only one word ("to fix" and "to cure" are pretty similar, right?). Then, there were two Chinese words for it (as you can see with the kanji), so the one Japanese word got split into two very similar words.

context_sentences.ja: ビエトは、Tofuguのオフィスで働いている時に、アジトでの発砲に関する電話を受けた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>connection</kanji> <kanji>related</kanji> to another <kanji>connection</kanji> obviously has some kind of <vocabulary>connection</vocabulary>, at least between all those meanings.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Viet is a yakuza, but I can say for sure that he is not connected to that crime.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトはヤクザだが、そのはんざいには関係してないとだん言できます。

context_sentences.en: Viet is wondering if he should cut his connections with the yakuza and just focus on his work at Tofugu.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトは、ヤクザとの関係をたってトーフグの仕事に専念するかどうかまよっています。

context_sentences.en: "He’s been married before and has three kids." "I know, but that has nothing to do with it."
context_sentences.ja: 「彼は前に結婚していて、子供も3人もいるのよ。」「知ってるわよ。でも、それとこれとは関係ないでしょ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>slope</kanji>s of the <kanji>god</kanji>s! What could this be? Well, it's mainly just a company, known as <vocabulary>Hanshin</vocabulary>. They're based in the area between Osaka and Kobe. Think of it this way: <ja>大阪</ja> + <ja>神戸</ja> = <ja>阪神</ja>! They're everywhere, though, and even have a baseball team (the Hanshin Tigers), so it's good to know.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I'm setting the Hanshin Electric Railway colored jelly by cooling it with ice.
context_sentences.ja: 阪神電車カラーのゼリーを氷でひやして固めているところです。

context_sentences.en: I am thinking about buying a newly-built house in the Hanshin district. About how much is the market price?
context_sentences.ja: 今度、阪神地区に新築の家を買おうと思ってるんですが、相場はいくらぐらいなんですか。

context_sentences.en: Oh my God! Hanshin Tigers fans dived off the Ebisu bridge down into the dirty river? Wow, they are nuts!
context_sentences.ja: うわぁ、阪神タイガースのファンたち、恵比寿橋からあの汚い川にダイブしたんだって？すげぇな、あいつらの頭大丈夫かよ！

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>front</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>front</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>front side</vocabulary> of it (kind of like how <ja>外面</ja> is the exterior because it's the outside face).
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Viet always puts his good man-ness to the front.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトはいつもいい人さを前面に出している。

context_sentences.en: Please find a box that has green on both the front and back sides.
context_sentences.ja: 前面も後面も両方とも緑色の箱をさがしてください。

context_sentences.en: Whenever we send a letter or a package, we put the Tofugu sticker on the front of it.
context_sentences.ja: 手紙や小包を送る時には、いつも前面にTofuguのステッカーを貼ります。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>ground</kanji>/<kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> is the surface that makes up the <vocabulary>ground</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>Earth's surface</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for <ja>面</ja> is what you'd expect. <ja>地</ja> on the other hand is <ja>じ</ja>, which is a bit different (though close sounding) to what you learned previously. Thank the Chinese and their ever changing language for this one. Think of <reading>Je</reading>sus laying on the ground, telling you how comfortable the ground is. You say "Jesus, you have to get off the ground, you have a dinner to go to," but he doesn't want to leave.

context_sentences.en: Fugu said that he'd rather live underground than underwater.
context_sentences.ja: 海の中じゃなくて地面の中に住めたらいいのに、とフグは言いました。

context_sentences.en: Our front yard doesn't have any grass, so the earth's surface gets really hot during summer.
context_sentences.ja: 家の前の庭は草が生えていないので、夏の間は地面がとても熱くなります。
