Master Roshi, from Dragonball, is standing in front of you (you thought he was a cartoon!). Then, he splits into a million versions of himself, creating a <reading>mob of Roshi</reading>s (<ja>まぼろし</ja>). This mob goes on to train many people to fight.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>memorize</kanji>d an <kanji>illusion</kanji>. You see it there, as if it's real, as if it's in your memory and brain. But it's not real. It's a <vocabulary>hallucination</vocabulary>.

data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Just don't forget the rendaku for <ja>底</ja>!

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>建てる</ja> is "to build." This is similar to that, but it's the version where you're not doing the building. Something is just getting built. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to be erected</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be built</vocabulary>. You can recognize that because of the <ja>つ</ja>, which tells you that <reading>two</reading> (<ja>つ</ja>) guys are building the building while you watch. So you're not doing it, they are, and it's just happening.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is shared with <ja>建てる</ja>, so if you know <ja>建てる</ja> then you should be able to read this word as well.

context_sentences.en: New high-rise buildings are being built one after another in Tokyo.
context_sentences.ja: 東京には、新しい高そうビルがぞくぞくと建っています。

context_sentences.en: Koichi's bronze statue was erected at the White House.
context_sentences.ja: ホワイトハウスに、コウイチのどうぞうが建ちました。

context_sentences.en: Salmon and I are discussing buying a pre-built home at the north end of the beach, but it’s a little expensive for us.
context_sentences.ja: サーモンと僕は、浜辺の北端に建つ家を買おうと相談してるんですが、ちょっと私達には値段が高いんですよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>thing</kanji> you <kanji>build</kanji> is a <vocabulary>building</vocabulary>. There aren't too many other things you build, at least not to this extent.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird. It's kun'yomi readings across the board, meaning your knowledge of <ja>建てる</ja> hopefully can come into play here. A building is something you build, so how do you say "to build"? It's <ja>建てる</ja> (<ja>たてる</ja>). Since it's a thing you build, it's a <ja><reading>たてもの</reading></ja>. This reading is a bit confusing, but hopefully after a while you'll get it if you get it wrong too many times! Maybe if you think about the building you're in and call it a <ja>建物</ja> a few times it'll sink in better?

context_sentences.en: This is very nicely designed building, isn't it?
context_sentences.ja: すてきなデザインの建物ですね。

context_sentences.en: It's only been a year since it was built, but this building is pretty dirty already, isn't it?
context_sentences.ja: 建てられてからまだ一年しかたってないのに、あの建物はもうずい分よごれているね。

context_sentences.en: "I’d like to go see the building with you so when would be convenient for you?" "Well, I’ll adjust my schedule accordingly."
context_sentences.ja: 「あなたとその建物を一緒に見に行きたいと思うのですが、いつがご都合よろしいですか？」「ええっと、あなたのご都合に合わせますよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: What you <kanji>build</kanji> up in <kanji>front</kanji> of other people is your public image. This is your <vocabulary>public behavior</vocabulary>, how you act around others you don't really know. This concept is surprisingly important in Japan, so you'll hear it often enough despite being such a strange concept in other places. You'll have to think of this like you're building buildings of personality in front of you. These show off who you are on the outside, but it protects what's on the inside.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is pretty strange. It's a lot like <ja>建物</ja> in that it's read as <ja>たて</ja>, which is like the word <ja>建てる</ja> even though the <ja>て</ja> isn't showing here. So, you'll have to remember it's read like <ja>建てる</ja> but the <ja>て</ja> gets pushed into the kanji.

context_sentences.en: Viet is good at separating his public and private selves.

context_sentences.en: Our official stance is that you can't see a doctor here without a letter of reference.

context_sentences.ja: よく「本音と建前」は日本独特の文化だと言われますが、実際は世界中に存在します。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>romance</kanji> you also have <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>! The romantic kind of mushy, gushy love. Be careful though. This word doesn't share its meaning with its kanji. But, that's how romance is. It gets all crazy and turns to love really fast.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. The fish is just so... so... handsome! You get hearts popping above your head every time you think about this koi!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>failure</kanji>, but "to failure" doesn't make sense. What happens when you experience failure, though? Well you get defeated, and you're also unsuccessful. So, this verb is <vocabulary>to be defeated</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be unsuccessful</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have been defeated. You lay there on the ground, and the fans around the stadium are disgusted with your performance. Some hipster walks up to you and says: "<reading>Yah, Boo</reading>" (<ja>やぶ</ja>) referring to how poorly you did. "No boo!" you reply back. "Yah boo" they say again.

context_sentences.en: The Blue Jays lost the game to the Red Socks with a score of 1-3.

context_sentences.en: As we all expected, Koichi was defeated again in the singing contest.

context_sentences.en: Did you hear that a guy got upset with Japan’s national hockey team when they were defeated in the first round of a preliminary game for the Olympics and threw some curry at them?

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fault</kanji> and a <kanji>failure</kanji>, all in one. This must have been one big <vocabulary>failure</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>mistake</vocabulary> you've made.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <ja>失</ja> gets shortened, though. Don't make that <ja>失敗</ja>.

context_sentences.en: When this player failed to bunt, this other player was caught stealing.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>win</kanji> and you have <kanji>failure</kanji>. When you are talking about both in one word, you have <vocabulary>victory or defeat</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>flourish</kanji> or <kanji>prosper</kanji>, so the verb vocab versions of these would be <vocabulary>to flourish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to prosper</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you flourish at? You're an amazing <vocabulary>soccer</vocabulary> (<ja>さか</ja>) player who flourishes and prospers no matter where you go to play this wonderful (but not as good as baseball) sport.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
When a <kanji>light</kanji> shines on how much you've <kanji>prosper</kanji>ed, it's a great <vocabulary>honor</vocabulary>. You don't feel like you did anything so special, but it's really a privilege for the light to come down on you like this.

Don't confuse this with <ja>栄光</ja>! With that one, you made things prosper and the light came after, making you look glorious. With this, light is shining on you, and you receive honor from it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know the <kanji>previous</kanji> part of your <kanji>nose</kanji>? The part of your nose I just chopped off? Well, you were lucky, as that was only the <vocabulary>tip of the nose</vocabulary>. Time to cut off the rest, next!
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. With <ja>鼻</ja> you learned that with the kanji. With <ja>先</ja> you learned that with the vocab. So, you should have all the pieces to be able to read this. Remember, body parts tend to change words into kun'yomi readings for some reason, no exception here.

context_sentences.en: You got mustard at the tip of your nose.
context_sentences.ja: 鼻先にマスタードがついてるよ。

context_sentences.en: When Fugu saw that the tip of Salmon’s nose was so red, he found it very cute.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Try singing a <kanji>nose</kanji> <kanji>song</kanji>. How does it sound? Like <vocabulary>humming</vocabulary> perhaps?
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings, probably because a <ja>鼻</ja> is a body part, and body parts do that to jukugo words. You know <ja>鼻</ja>'s reading from the kanji (<ja>はな</ja>) and you know <ja>歌</ja>'s reading from the vocabulary word <ja>歌</ja> (<ja>うた</ja>). Combine them together and you have a very nice humming tune and reading, <ja>はなうた</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Koichi was humming while making his nose swell.

context_sentences.en: Viet was happily riding his bicycle while humming.

context_sentences.en: LMAO! You are just terrible at humming.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>nose</kanji> with <kanji>blood</kanji> is a nose with a <vocabulary>nosebleed</vocabulary>. It is a <vocabulary>bloody nose</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You already know <ja>鼻</ja>'s reading from the kanji and vocab, and you should know the vocab reading of <ja>血</ja> as well. Put them together and you have <ja>はなち</ja>, though you want to change the <ja>ち</ja> to <ja>ぢ</ja>. Alternatively, it's possible (though less common, but it doesn't matter if you're turning it to kanji via an IME anyways) to write it as <ja>はなじ</ja>. I guess that blood added a little tenten (it represents the blood coming out of that nose!). Spurt spurt spurt.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has <ja>曜日</ja> in it. But what day of the week is it? Either you found you drank too much on Friday, so on this day's morning you're laying right on the ground of earth. Or, maybe you just want to sleep in after staying up late on Friday. Either way, this day you lay close to the earth is <vocabulary>Saturday</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has <ja>曜日</ja> in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>water</kanji> day of the week is where the water flows from. Think of your entire week as a big hill, with Wednesday (hump day) being in the middle. This hump is a hill. What originates from hills? Water! That's why Water day is <vocabulary>Wednesday</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>borrow</kanji> a <kanji>house</kanji> you are <vocabulary>renting a house</vocabulary>. Also, this is a <vocabulary>house for rent</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but in this case the second kanji can be read as either the on'yomi or kun'yomi. You haven't seen the kun'yomi for <ja>家</ja> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you're <vocabulary>renting a house</vocabulary>, someone has to give you the keys and let you in and stuff. You're only renting, after all. So when they let you in they'll say, "Here's a <reading>shack</reading> for <reading>yah</reading>! (<ja>しゃくや</ja>) Enjoy!"

By the way, in the secondary reading, the <ja>しゃく</ja> goes to <ja>しゃっ</ja>. You'll see <ja>しゃくや</ja> more often, though.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something comes off. Something is removed. No direct object here. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to come off</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be removed</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as <ja>取る</ja>.

When you've pulled it out, you've come to an arrangement, though they've pulled some of your decision out too.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji, which you might have guessed already since there's hiragana sticking out of both of them. The <ja>取り</ja> comes <ja>取る</ja> and the <ja>決め</ja> comes from <ja>決める</ja>. Put them together and what have you got? Bibbidi bobbidi <ja>とりきめ</ja>!

If you're not, think of the cute thing being a cow. Then you say, "that <reading>cow<ja>はいい</ja></reading>" (<ja>かわい</ja>), or "that cow is good" because it's so cute.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>silver</kanji> <kanji>seat</kanji> isn't some crazy kingdom where the king sits upon a silver seat. It is a famous place in Tokyo. Perhaps if you read the reading it will become more apparent what the meaning is (since they're the same). This silver seat place is <vocabulary>Ginza</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>弁当</ja> is "bento"? Well, the <ja>弁</ja> in this word comes from that, so pretend it means "bento." Then, when you have a <kanji>train station</kanji> to go along with the bento, you have a <vocabulary>train station bento</vocabulary>. As you might think, a train station bento is just a bento that's sold at a train station. Easy!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You have your bow and you use it to shoot things, sure, but you've also covered it in candy so you can eat it when you're waiting out in the woods waiting for a buck to come by. You lick your candy bow and say: "<reading>yummy</reading>!" (<ja>ゆみ</ja>). Imagine the taste of your bow. What taste would make you say yummy?

context_sentences.en: Yeah, Lawson is open 24/7, but, you know, I don’t think they carry bows and arrows.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Something <kanji>below</kanji> your <kanji>writing</kanji> isn't what you want to necessarily publish to the world. It's below your writing, after all. This is merely a <vocabulary>rough draft</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading, as you can maybe guess from the hiragana sticking out. If you know the readings of the words <ja>下</ja> and <ja>書く</ja> separately, you should be able to combine them into one reading.

data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from <ja>書く</ja> and <ja>入れる</ja>. Combine those two words to get the reading of this word.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is the <kanji>way</kanji> of <kanji>writing</kanji> (kind of like how <ja>見方</ja> is the way of seeing). A better way to say this though would be to call it <vocabulary>penmanship</vocabulary>, though. How's your <ja>書き方</ja>? Mine is terrible.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>flat object</kanji>s but <kanji>what</kanji> amount of flat objects? This word is asking that question: "<vocabulary>how many flat objects</vocabulary> are there?" If this doesn't make sense, think back to words like <ja>何回</ja> or <ja>何年</ja> which ask "how many ____" just like this one.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know the word <ja>皿</ja> (plate) and the word <ja>洗う</ja> (to wash), right? You can probably guess dish washing is happening here, but this is a noun, so it's the idea of <vocabulary>dishwashing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>doing dishes</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the individual vocab words (you can tell because there's a bit of hiragana stuck on there). It's the reading for <ja>皿</ja> and <ja>洗う</ja> combined.

data.meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>sun</kanji> <kanji>cook</kanji>s something, and that something is you, it is giving you <vocabulary>sunburn</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings here are the vocab kun'yomi readings. You have <ja>ひ</ja> for <ja>日</ja> and <ja>や</ja> for <ja>焼け</ja> (which you learned with the vocab). Combine it with some sunscreen and hopefully you'll prevent the <vocabulary>sunburn</vocabulary>.

context_sentences.en: It seems like my daughter is deeply in love with that tan young man.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bake</kanji>d <kanji>bird</kanji> isn't just any bird, it's <vocabulary>roast chicken</vocabulary>. You may also know it by its romanized Japanese name: <vocabulary>yakitori</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings. With <ja>焼き</ja>, you can use the reading you learned with the kanji. With <ja>鳥</ja> just remember back to the vocab word, <ja>とり</ja>. Combine and eat.

context_sentences.en: Yakitori is essential for my life.

If you go to Japan look out for <ja>焼肉</ja> places (same meaning/reading). They are good, if you're into meat at least.
data.reading_mnemonic: <ja>焼き</ja> uses the reading you learned with the kanji. <ja>肉</ja> does too. Combine them together onto one skewer and enjoy.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're standing around a <vocabulary>smoke</vocabulary> machine. It's billowing up smoke. Strangely, your buddy Bill Murray is here too. For some reason, he loves the smoke, and he puts his head in it, breathing it in deeply until he goes into a coughing fit. data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the two words <ja>禅</ja> and <ja>寺</ja> put together. The <ja>てら</ja> gets changed to <ja>でら</ja>, though.

In terms of when it's pronounced <ja>ぜんじ</ja>, if you put this word onto the end of the name of a <ja>禅寺</ja> the pronunciation changes to <ja>ぜんじ</ja>. It makes sense - it's more like a jukugo word that way (not that the original isn't, but you can see the separation of words coming together which gives the hint that it's a kun'yomi combo reading). Anyways, you may need a zen temple to keep your mind pure enough to remember this, but it's a good thing to keep in mind if you can.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>permit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to permit</vocabulary>. It also means <vocabulary>to forgive</vocabulary>, in that "I'll permit it this time... but only this time." Look out for <ja>許さない</ja> in TV shows, too. It means "I won't permit this!" or "I won't forgive you!"
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to allow it. <reading>You're</reading> (<ja>ゆる</ja>) allowed to do it this one time, okay?

You can differentiate this from the future word <ja>乱す</ja> because with <ja>れる</ja> you know it is <reading>rare</reading> for it to be like this. You aren't doing it, but it just happens on occasion (rarely) so you take advantage of it.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a food pretty specific to Japan, making it a slightly weird one to learn. You have a <kanji>Japanese Plum</kanji>. Then you have <kanji>dry</kanji>. So when the Japanese plum is dried, it's not a dried plum (that would be too easy), it is a <vocabulary>pickled plum</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pickled ume</vocabulary>. If you know the name of this food, you can call it by that too: <vocabulary>umeboshi</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one, like the meaning, is kind of strange. It's the kun'yomi readings, so apologies in advance for that. You have <ja>うめ</ja> plus <ja>ぼし</ja>, which comes from <ja>干す</ja> though the <ja>し</ja> is stuffed inside the <ja>干</ja> for some reason. It's also rendaku'd. Basically, everything is all screwed up, so you know, deal with it. This food is awesome, and common, so you have to learn it. I guess the pickling process has mangled the reading of this word. At least it tastes good.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a tough one. When you <kanji>compare</kanji> <kanji>examples</kanji> (in this case of numbers) you are figuring out the <vocabulary>proportion</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>ratio</vocabulary>. A ratio, for example, has one number on top of another. They are examples being compared. Same with proportions. Without two things to compare, proportion doesn't make sense. That's why when you compare examples, you are dealing with proportions or ratios.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>mix</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to mix</vocabulary>. This is when you're doing the mixing. You can remember this because "<reading>there</reading> (<ja>ぜる</ja>) is much mixing to be done so it's best if you just do it because nobody else will."

The connotation for this word is you can't distinguish the things you're mixing, like combining paints, which become one mixed color that isn't two separate colors anymore.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're doing mixing like your <reading>ma</reading> (<ja>ま</ja>) taught you, which is why when you do the mixing things get done around here a lot faster.

You can also use the level 5 vocab <ja>交ぜる</ja> to help you remember as it has the same meaning and reading!

context_sentences.en: Koichi founded a fugu poison research center with his own private funds.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは、私財を投じて河豚毒研究センターを作った。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>wealth</kanji> you <kanji>borrow</kanji> is your <vocabulary>debt</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Make sure you remember <ja>ざい</ja> over <ja>さい</ja>, though. Why? Because you got all this debt trying to buy your way into <reading>Z</reading>ion.

context_sentences.en: It's not good to take out debt if you don't know how to pay it back.
context_sentences.ja: 返す目どが立っていないのに、借財をするのは良くないよ。

context_sentences.en: Is it true that Tofugu has a large amount of debt?
context_sentences.ja: トーフグが多がくの借財をかかえているというのは本当ですか？

context_sentences.en: After Fugu’s assassination, it became clear that the only thing he left behind for Salmon was debt.
context_sentences.ja: フグが暗殺された後、サーモンに残されたのは借財だけだということが明らかになった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>take along</kanji> and <kanji>continue</kanji> something, you are creating <vocabulary>serial</vocabulary> version of it. Come along now. Okay, continue! Come along now. Okay, continue! This is how Lord of the Rings was made, probably. Come along now.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: This all-you-can-ride ticket is limited to three days of consecutive use.
context_sentences.ja: この乗り放題切ぷは、連続する三日間のみ有こうです。

context_sentences.en: The case of serial murders was the sole topic of the morning news.
context_sentences.ja: 朝のニュースは、連続殺人事けんの話で持ち切りでした。

context_sentences.en: Life with you is truly full of surprises. I can’t believe you were late for work for 365 consecutive days!
context_sentences.ja: 君との人生は本当に驚きの連続だよ。まさか三百六十五日連続で遅刻するなんて思ってもみなかったよ。
